TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 23 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth do humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government:

1. Uphold the principle that the seeds and cuttings of plants are a public resource and a common heritage to all and that accordingly seeds should be freely available to all, freely multipliable, able to be sold, exchanged, exported and imported by anyone who wishes. This is seen as a matter of national food security.

2. Recognise that plant breeding is a highly co-operative venture often involving private enterprise at the very last stages after basic seed collection , storage, and research has been publicly funded.
3. In view of the aforementioned paragraphs, recognise that any system giving ' property' or ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises is inappropriate and unjust.
4. Recognise that legislation establishing plant patenting schemes overseas has had serious adverse effects namely:
(i) a slowing-down of scientific information exchange and exchanges in basic plant breeding materials, that is, germ plasm,
(ii) subordination and/or curtailment of public breeding programmes,
(iii) farmer unrest at seed prices,
(iv) monopoly control of seed production and sales has passed into the hands of giant petrochemical and drug corporations also marketing crop chemicals,
(v) increased uniformity of crop varieties leading to a vulnerability to pest and disease attack.
5. Reject any proposal to legislate for any system such as the drafted Plant Variety Rights Act, which gives exclusive ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GIETZELT

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 29 citizens of Australia :

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. We, the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth, do humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government:
1. Note that legislation establishing plant breeders' rights in other countries has had serious adverse effects, namely:

a. Virtual monopoly control of seed production has passed into the hands of a few large international corporations seeking to profit from the exclusive rights over plant genetic materials created by such legislation.

b. The varieties of seeds available have been restricted mainly to hybrids which will not reproduce truly and will not grow without the aid of artificial fertilisers and pesticides, thus maximising corporate profits without regard for the interests of growers and consumers.
c. The genetic diversity of crops has been eroded, rendering them vulnerable to disease and other environmental threats.

2. Recognise that maintenance of the genetic diversity of plant varieties is crucial to the continued well-being of the Australian nation, and take all necessary steps to preserve and promote such genetic diversity as a public resource and to prevent exclusive control over plant genetic materials from falling into private hands.

3. Defend the vital interests of Australian farmers and gardeners, independent Australian seed companies and their employees, and consumers of Australian farm and garden produce, by rejecting any proposal to legislate for the establishment of plant breeders' rights in Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Law Act
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: We the undersigned citizens of Australia, concerned about the high and increasing rate of divorce and family breakdown, convinced that the Family Law Act has weakened marriage by making divorce a trivial matter, the present Act paying scant regard to its own definition of marriage as a life-long union; and believing that the legal bond of marriage should be strengthened, humbly petition for the Family Law Act and the Marriage Act to be amended in order to:
(1) Reject any moves towards divorce by post
(2) Restore the former prohibition of marriages between close relatives by blood or by marriage

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate: Is it true that the position of Australian Ambassador to the United States of America is now vacant and that shortly the position of Australian Ambassador to Japan will become vacant? Does the Government regard it as important that these posts, involving two of our most important political and trading partners, are not un- occupied for any length of time? Will the Minister give an assurance that those appointed will be appointed in accordance with the Prime Minister's election promise that there will be no jobs for the boys and that they will not be Ministers of the present Government? In other words, will the Minister give an assurance that these posts will be treated differently from those of High Commissioner to London, Ambassador to the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation, Consul-General in New York, Consul-General in Los Angeles and High Commissioner to New Zealand, all of which were filled on a jobs for the boys basis?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I presume that the appointment of Mr Barnard to a diplomatic post under the Whitlam Government would also be classified by Senator Button as a job for the boys, Mr Barnard having been the Deputy Prime Minister and demoted from that position.
—Absolutely; but you were going to end all that, you will recall.

—I can understand the difficulties that Senator Button has with a reminder of the past. It is true that Sir Nicholas Parkinson has retired from the post of Australian Ambassador to the United States of America. My understanding is that a very distinguished diplomat-David Anderson, who was with the United Nations-is acting in that position at the moment. It is true also that Sir James Plimsoll is to leave Japan in the near future, I think to take up a vice-regal appointment. Both posts are important. I understand that the Government has not made the appointments as yet. The Government will appoint people fully equipped to carry out Australia's representation in both countries in the knowledge that they are important posts. It is extraordinary that when the Whitlam Government was in power it was the strongest proponent of the fact that it was a good thing to appoint Ministers, such as Mr Barnard or, in our case, Sir Victor Garland and, of course, the very distinguished appointment of Sir Robert Cotton to New York. In government the Australian Labor Party saw this very clearly; in Opposition it seeks to sneer. Let me simply say that the record of previous Liberal Ministers serving abroad in diplomatic posts has been of the highest order and, indeed, our appointments to diplomatic posts will remain so.

—Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. I ask the Minister: Is it not a fact that following the reprehensible circumstance he has just disclosed-Mr Barnard's appointment to the foreign service by the Whitlam Government-the Prime Minister, whom Senator Sir John Carrick represents in this place, said that that was deplorable and 'There will be no more jobs for the boys'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware of that. I will look it up. Nor am I aware of that reference. But there will be no jobs for the boys. I repeat that in all cases in which appointments have been made they have been of distinguished people who have performed their duties admirably and with great distinction for Australia.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Defence able to confirm that some of the United States nuclear submarines are now approaching the end of their useful life? I am informed that it is some 100 of them. Is the Minister aware that there have been reports in the United States Press that that country has been considering dumping those submarines at the bottom of the ocean off the West Coast of the United States? If the Minister is not aware of the details of this matter-something that affects the whole world-will he ascertain the actual situation, discuss the matter in Cabinet and make the Government's attitude known to this Parliament and to the United States?
—I do not have any information--
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I placed a question relating to that matter on the Notice Paper some time ago.
—Exactly the same?
—Not exactly.
—It has to be exactly the same.
—Mr President, I am asking you to make a ruling.
—Senator Jones, I ask whether in your opinion your question is reasonably identical to the question asked by Senator Townley or whether it covers the same aspect. There is a difference.
—I believe that it covers the same aspect, Mr President.
—There is a difference then, Senator. I call the Attorney-General.

—I personally have no knowledge of the matters that have been raised by Senator Townley. I propose to refer the matter to the Minister for Defence. So Senator Jones will be in exactly the same position as he was seeking to maintain.

—I refer the Minister for Social Security to the long list of social security cases awaiting hearing before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and to the fact that there is an increasing backlog of such cases. Can he tell the Senate how many cases are awaiting hearing? What is the waiting time in each State? Have those figures increased in the last 12 months? Is the main reason for the delays the time it takes his Department to provide the necessary information to the Tribunal? If so, will he take action to improve the situation so that justice can be provided to those who seek it?

—I think the figures requested by the honourable senator are available, although I do not have them with me at the moment. There has been a quite real problem in this area. I acknowledge that. It is a problem which the Department has sought to deal with by recruiting additional qualified staff. Notwithstanding that there is a difficulty with respect to unemployment in this country, it has proved not easy to get staff who are qualified for this work. In particular I have been advised by my officers that they have had difficulty in recruiting lawyers, who are an essential part of the process of putting the requisite material into shape to go before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Considerable effort has gone into trying to rectify the difficulties. I will obtain up to date figures for the honourable senator and will also advise him of the up to date staffing position. I do not have any of that information at my fingertips.

—Mr President, my question is directed to you. Is it a fact that draft Hansard transcripts of the proceedings of Senate estimates and standing committees are made available to witnesses who appear before those Committees for correction of fact as well as sense? Are these draft transcripts available also to Ministers who appear before these committees? If so, will you consider making them available to honourable senators so that they can make whatever corrections they think are necessary before transcripts are printed in the form of the daily Hansard?

—I will take up the matter raised by Senator Martin. I do not see any reason why honourable senators should not be given Hansard proofs for correction in the same way as they are provided to witnesses.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: FUTURE USE OF PRESENT PARLIAMENT HOUSE

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which relates to a matter of policy, is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I ask whether he is aware of allegations that were made on the Canberra regional news of the Australian Broadcasting Commission last night that, on completion of the new and permanent Parliament House, the Parliament House that we now occupy is to be pulled down so that it will not 'spoil the view', presumably of the new edifice. I take it that as a matter of policy the Government has considered what future use this building will be put to. I ask the Minister now to say whether destruction of this building is even contemplated and to ask the Government to make an early statement on the uses to which it is likely to be put.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not hear the report last night but I think I heard such an allegation this morning. Such an allegation is not based on fact. Those honourable senators and honourable members of another place who have served on the Joint Standing Committee on the New and Permanent House will know that an essential feature of the acceptance of the design of the new Parliament House was that it would be integrated into the Parliamentary Triangle and would sit in a vista looking across from the Australian War Memorial to the new Parliament House with this building remaining where it is. As quite a number of honourable senators and honourable members will know, that was fundamental to the acceptance of the design. Everybody stressed that this building, being of an historic nature and of extremely attractive design, should remain. Various suggestions have been made as to its future use, including a convention centre; but no final decision has been made, except that it was implicit in the decision on the site of the new Parliament House that this building should remain where it is.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: INTERNATIONAL NARCOTICS CONTROL BOARD REPORT ON CANNABIS

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Health noted the contents of the latest report to the United Nations of the International Narcotics Control Board, especially in relation to the drug cannabis? In view of the new evidence it contains of the harmful effects of cannabis, will the Minister ensure that extracts of the report are widely publicised and distributed to all relevant bodies in Australia?

—I have become aware lately of new and emerging international evidence. I believe that an article in the Australian newspaper a couple of weeks ago drew attention to some of the latest information. The writer of that article probably drew upon the United Nations report to which Senator Walters has referred. I think all honourable senators would believe that those people interested in the effects of cannabis and other drugs should have access to all available information. I do not know whether it is possible for the Government to ensure the wide distribution of the information from the United Nations international control agency to which Senator Walters referred. I agree with the honourable senator that we would want that information to be in as many hands as possible.

—Will the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs explain why the Aboriginal Development Commission has been left with a shortfall of $1.1m? Does he acknowledge that a rapid increase in the administrative responsibilities of the ADC has created unavoidable higher administrative costs? Is the Minister aware that, because of the shortfall, programs such as land purchases, housing loans and Aboriginal enterprise schemes are in jeopardy? How can the Government reconcile this development with its public commitment to self-management for Aboriginals?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Aboriginal Development Commission has not been under- funded by the Department. The Department has not promised the Aboriginal Development Commission an additional $1.1m. Press reports which have asserted that have been misleading. Expenditure by the Aboriginal Development Commission until the end of February this year shows that the ADC will have overspent its administrative budget, as distinct from its program budget, by the end of the financial year. The Department supported an increase in the Additional Estimates for the ADC's costs of administration. The Aboriginal Development Commission, like all other parts of government, was required to offset as much of this increased cost as it could against its other programs. In fact, it was required to offset this increased cost against increased revenue which it expected to receive during the financial year.

ANSWER.PARA: A reassessment of the ADC's financial position since the Additional Estimates were finalised has suggested that a case for some extra funds can be supported. Appropriate steps are now being taken to follow up and to examine the ways in which that increased entitlement might be pursued. I might add that it has taken considerable time and effort to obtain the information on which that assessment might be made.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment aware of the concern being expressed in Brisbane in relation to the arrival of USS Truxtun, a nuclear-powered warship due in Brisbane on Thursday? Can the Minister assure the Senate that all necessary safeguards are present and that precautions are being taken to ensure that there is no danger of any leakage of nuclear waste into the Brisbane River and/or the waters of Moreton Bay?

—I was not aware that a United States warship was coming to Brisbane this week. Honourable senators will know that the visit of a nuclear- powered ship is not new to this country. It has occurred before. There are procedures whereby any ship that visits should adopt appropriate practices. I would not imagine that there is any danger either to the people of Brisbane or to Moreton Bay from the visit of the ship, certainly not as regards its nuclear reactor or its nuclear power. I would imagine that the fact that a number of United States sailors might be getting shore leave might be of more interest to the people of Brisbane than the source of power which drives the submarine.

—Has the Attorney-General seen today's report that the United States District Court in Washington has made orders requiring Australian shipping conferences to supply information to the United States Justice Department to enable it to decide whether the ocean transportation of commodities between Australia, New Zealand and the United States involves possible breaches of United States antitrust law? Does the Attorney recall his answer in the Senate on 14 September 1978 in response to a question from you, Mr President, before you donned your present wig, when in relation to the then recently concluded discussions with then United States Attorney-General Bell on the subject of extraterritorial enforcement of United States antitrust laws, he said: 'there was a desire on both sides to reach an agreement. . . . We are hoping at this stage that such an agreement will eventuate within six months'? Given that that statement was made, as I said, in September 1978, will the Attorney indicate why after all this time and a number of meetings between him and successive United States Attorneys-General, his negotiating skill has still failed to produce any such agreement?

—Of course, the short answer to Senator Evans's question is that it takes two sides to make an agreement. I would have thought, and I have said so in a number of statements that have been issued by me and in a number of answers I have made in the Senate in answer to this question, that it has proved to be an extraordinarily difficult process. For quite a period it looked as though nothing was going to be achieved. Last June when the Prime Minister met President Reagan he raised the matter at that level because it seemed as though it needed raising at that level. There has been a revival of discussions with the United States Justice Department, and I think I have already indicated that I raised the matter with my counterpart, Mr William French Smith. The latest position is that there are to be discussions between officials in Washington in the middle of May next and renewed efforts are to be made to see whether an agreement can be reached. If those discussions are successful or seem to indicate that success is reasonably likely, I would propose to have further discussions with Mr French Smith later in the year, probably June or July.
—Mr President, I have a supplementary question. Is the Attorney proposing to take any action to resist the application of the United States District Court decision made last week?

—This matter, which is the subject of the question from Senator Evans and of a report in the Australian Financial Review this morning, is of itself quite a long one. Indeed, when these proceedings were commenced they were the subject of quite strong protests from the Australian Government because we were not given any notification of them. The decision that has been mentioned has been made by the parties. Of course, we have been following it closely. The judgment has only just come to hand and has not yet been able to be studied. I would not like to comment at this stage on the next step that can be made, if any. Naturally, it is a matter which will be urgently studied.

—Has the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology been drawn to a report in Saturday's Melbourne Age quoting Professor Max Brennan, Chairman of the Australian Research Grants Committee, in which he stated that government support for scientific research in universities had fallen in real terms by two-thirds in the 16 years the ARGC had been in operation? Can the Minister inform the Senate whether it is a fact that the success rate for applicants to the Committee has fallen from 77 per cent to 64 per cent over the last three years and that this year 180 fewer applicants were successful than in 1980? Is Professor Brennan correct in his assessment that Australia's university research effort is suffering as a result of a lack of Government financial commitment? Is it true that many important research projects are being forced to close or, in many instances, are being lost to overseas research institutions? I quote an example of this with respect to the development at Flinders University by Professor De Bruin of an oxygen probe, an energy saving device. Will the Minister assure the Senate that the Government will study Professor Brennan's claims and reconsider its commitment to university research in order to enable Australia to maintain a position of international prominence with respect to our research effort?

—I have noted the comments made by Professor Brennan. My colleague the Minister for Science and Technology advises me that he also is aware of them , is studying them and will have discussions with Professor Brennan on these and other matters on 4 May. Of course the funding of research through the ARGC is only one of a number of methods of research grants made by the Government, but certainly the Government believes in the importance of the continued role of universities in basic research. The matters raised by Professor Brennan of course will be studied and considered in the Budget context.

—My question, which is directed to Senator Durack, is on a two -based approach, first as the Attorney-General and, second, as a former member, along with me and Senator Townley, of a committee that looked at certain aspects of security. I put it to the Attorney-General, in light of the precedent whereby a Senate committee investigated the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation within a certain ambit: Will he consider such a committee following up the Chapman Pincher allegations about whether Mr Ellis was a mole in the Australian security apparatus?

—I think the question of whether there should be parliamentary scrutiny of intelligence organisations, particularly ASIO, has been debated considerably in this chamber in recent years. The Government has taken the view that it is not appropriate that a parliamentary committee be established to oversee the operations of ASIO. That is a view which I certainly believe is correct. I believe that we have in recent times established a satisfactory way of providing for accountability by ASIO and I do not see any need for the establishment of a parliamentary committee for that purpose or to investigate any matter which may have been raised, in this case by Mr Chapman Pincher.

—Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. I ask the Attorney-General, in view of his answer, whether he means in effect that Senator Withers and the late Senator Greenwood were wrong when they dragooned the Senate, by virtue of their majority on the committee of which he and I were members. That committee interrogated ASIO Director Barbour.
—I know that I did not deal with that aspect of the question which Senator Mulvihill squarely raised, but the fact of the matter is that the committee to which he referred--
—A very illustrious committee.

—I say nothing about the membership of the committee, but I do not dissent from what the honourable senator has said. The fact of the matter is that that committee was set up to investigate one of the most extraordinary incidents that ever occurred in the government of this country; namely, the raid by an Attorney-General on the Organisation. Although the committee had to investigate some aspects, it was--
—It was a political stunt. Why don't you tell the truth?

—Talking about political stunts, that was a remarkable performance by the Attorney-General of the day. The Senate and, indeed, large sections of the Australian community were very concerned about it. As I understand it, that was what the committee was set up to do.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: MOOMBA TO STONY POINT OIL PIPELINE

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister for National Development and Energy, concerns the union walk-out on the Moomba to Stony Point oil pipeline in South Australia. Is the Minister aware of the importance of the pipeline to the future economic development of South Australia, not only through the liquefaction plant but also through the possibility of a refinery and a petrochemical works? Is the Minister aware also that construction workers on the site are paid around $850 a week and that the disputed claims are estimated to be in the vicinity of an additional $700 a week per man? Will the Minister draw to the attention of the Australian Workers Union the disastrous effect that such irresponsible claims and a long shut-down may have upon the development of South Australia and the employment prospects thereby provided?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have repeatedly outlined the significance of the pipeline which is to run from Moomba to Stony Point near Whyalla. As honourable senators would know, the pipeline will have an initial capacity, without pressure, of some 35,000 barrels of liquid a day and, under pressure, of 80,000 barrels a day. Eighty thousand barrels a day is one-fifth of the output of Bass Strait. That is significant in itself. As the fields in the Cooper Basin find oil and move from exploration to development, the pipeline will become more and more significant not only to the development of South Australia and its industries-that is significant enough-but also as an insurance policy for Australia should there be any interruption at all to our oil supplies from abroad or from Bass Strait.

ANSWER.PARA: The answer to the honourable senator's question is that that pipeline is of very great significance. I am aware of the plans to set up a mini-refinery at Stony Point and also to go in for petrochemical processing. I am aware that the wages paid to pipeline workers are of a high order. I am not precisely aware of the accuracy of the figures quoted. I will draw the attention of my colleague the Minister for Industrial Relations to the substance of Senator Hill's question. I will ask him to take all appropriate steps within his power to communicate to those persons concerned the vital need to finish that pipeline on time.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: EFFECT OF TELEVISION ADVERTISEMENTS AND PROGRAMS ON EPILEPTICS

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Communications or possibly the Minister for Health aware that during the last year flashing lights , numbers and letters have been used and are still being used in many television advertisements and programs? Is it an established fact that flashing lights are harmful to people suffering from epilepsy and can induce seizures? Has any research been done in this area? In view of the number of hours that some children are reported to be watching television, what steps will the Minister take to prevent such health hazards?

—I can confirm that much of what the honourable senator asks about in her question is correct. There is a form of epilepsy called, I think, photic epilepsy which responds to the repetition of flashing lights. I recall from a previous incarnation that if we wanted to test some people with an EEG we sometimes used a flashing light to see whether it would bring out abnormalities in the EEG. It is therefore correct that there could be concern if people were exposed to inappropriate forms of light stimulation. I think the honourable senator's question is one which might be referred most appropriately to the Minister for Communications so that if it has any health connotations he can, at least, be aware of them. However, the honourable senator does raise a matter which is not without significance and which I think warrants further examination .

—My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. With the devolution of recruitment functions from the Public Service Board to individual federal departments and in light of the Federal Government's policy on spending restraints within the Public Service, has an evaluation been made of the additional cost to departments as a whole in advertising individually in newspapers for other than the higher grade position vacancies as against the cost of the Board's multiple recruitment program?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware whether any evaluation has been made of increased costs that may arise from individual advertisements. I will seek that information either from my Department, as to whether it has any figures, or from the Public Service Board regarding whether any study has been made there. As soon as I have any information, I will see that the Senate is advised.

—Has the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs read the comments of Mr Gilliver, who is inquiring into homeless youth for the National Youth Advisory Group, that the chief cause of homelessness is unemployment? What new plans does the Government have for creating jobs for young people as all past schemes have proved very ineffective in solving the problem? Does the Government intend to continue its now common catchcry that all the ills in the economy are due to the Whitlam Government and the unions and to do nothing itself?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 12 April this year the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs made a statement with regard to a national drive for youth jobs. In that statement he made mention of the fact that the Commonwealth Employment Service will conduct a concerted drive throughout Australia during April to find work experience and jobs for last year's school leavers. He said that all of the 240 Commonwealth Employment Service officers and 148 Employment Service agencies in Australia would be involved in the drive. He said that the aim was to find positions for young people under the Special Youth Employment Training Program. I understand that in the last year, 1980-81, some 76,000 young Australians were assisted under this training program and the great majority of those jobs were found in private enterprise.

ANSWER.PARA: As the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs has said, as many people as possible will be assisted under this and other training programs this year. It is hoped that, through the training programs, work experience programs and in other ways, as wide an opportunity for employment as possible will be given to those young people who are seeking work experience and permanent jobs. I think that if we were to look at the programs of the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs and indeed other departments we would find that considerable effort is made to assist those who are seeking employment. I hope that as a result of the special national drive in April employers, State governments, local governments and others will join together to assist as many young people as possible to find the work experience and the permanent jobs that they seek.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Defence to the announcement that the future of existing fixed wing aircraft, such as Trackers and Skyhawks, is to be considered by a Defence working party with a view to paying them off as soon as practicable. The Minister will be aware that Tracker aircraft have proved very successful in the role of northern surveillance along extensive coastline and over isolated terrain. I ask the Minister: Will the Government, in considering the future of the Fleet Air Arm, take into account the invaluable experience gained by fixed wing aircrew and the excellent surveillance record of the Trackers in the north and redeploy them to service in the north until such time as the Mirage squadron is in operation in northern Australia?

—The factors mentioned by Senator Kilgariff will be taken into account by the working party. It would not be appropriate to indicate what the finding is likely to be. The report is not due until 1 June this year. However, even when a fighter squadron has been deployed to Darwin, there will be a need for coastal surveillance to continue to be conducted by specialised aircraft. Currently, the Darwin off-shore approaches are patrolled by contract Nomad Searchmaster radar-equipped aircraft; secondly, the Australian fishing zone is patrolled by Orion aircraft; and, thirdly, littoral flights are made by contract light twin-engined aircraft.

—My question is directed to the Attorney-General in his capacity as principal legal officer to the Government in the colour television affair last week. I ask: Is it not a fact that all persons entering Australia are required to answer, orally, at their point of entry, whether they have any goods to declare and/or whether it is their signature on the Customs form? Can the Minister say whether such questions were posed by the Customs officers to Mr MacKellar last October and what his answers were to the oral questions?

—I am not in a position to answer that question. I will take note of it. I point out that papers have been tabled. Information as to what officials said at the time is in those papers which are available to all senators and members.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. Is it a fact that industrial disputation on the waterfront has placed in jeopardy live sheep exports to Kuwait and that, as a first step, a Kuwait company, which I think is a government instrumentality, not only is easing down reliance on Australia for imports, but also has arranged to spend $ US180m on a joint venture with Brazil in a plan to rear five million sheep each year to eliminate completely imports from Australia? What steps have been taken, if any, to reverse this unfortunate decision and to ensure a share of the Kuwait market for Australian live sheep exports? Have the unions involved been made aware that their industrial disputation has finally placed in jeopardy the whole of that livelihood?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The export of live sheep from Australia has been bedevilled by a number of industrial disputes. There has been a series of concerns within the meat industry about the export of live as against slaughtered beasts. The honourable senator would be aware of the very extensive efforts which have been made by exporters, the Government and unions to try to arrive at common ground in this matter and of their attempts to go overseas to ensure that the difficulties can be worked out and that the export of live sheep can proceed in a way which is beneficial to Australia as a whole and to the various sectors which benefit from it. I was not aware that this industry, in particular, was suffering from industrial disputes on the waterfront, which I take to be a quite different series of industrial disputes from the ones which have affected meat workers. I am not in a position to deny that that is so because there has been very extensive industrial disputation on the waterfront over the last year or more.

ANSWER.PARA: The facts as put forward by the honourable senator in his question are probably correct. In light of the Government's concern about the previous activity which has threatened meat exports, I have little doubt that the Minister will be very concerned about the matters which have been raised. I will ask him to provide me with detailed information on the matter raised by the honourable senator, because, for a substantial section of the livestock industry in Australia, access to exporting of live sheep has proved to be a very valuable asset.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment. Bearing in mind that the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of Discrimination against women was signed on behalf of the Australian Government in July 1980 but has not yet been ratified and hence is not yet legally binding in Australia, can the Minister say when the Government intends to proceed with ratification of that Convention? If some impediments lie in the way of the ratification, what are they and how solvable are they? Finally, what steps is the Government taking to ensure in the meantime that the spirit of the Convention is operating to the advancement and advantage of women in this country?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I begin by assuring Senator Haines that Australia regards the Convention as a most important international instrument relating to women's rights. We are working towards ratification just as we are working towards a policy of equality of opportunity, freedom from discrimination and equal status for women. Honourable senators may be aware that there was a meeting of Ministers dealing with human rights held in Alice Springs in November 1980. It was agreed that Commonwealth and State governments would work actively towards ratification. The Commonwealth and State officials have been examining the various laws and practices within their jurisdictions in order to ensure consistency between the Commonwealth and the States with the principles and objectives set out in the Convention.

ANSWER.PARA: There have been subsequent meetings. I understand that the Commonwealth and State Ministers have met since then in April, August and November 1981 and again in February 1982. They had before them papers prepared by officials who were trying to progress this matter. Good progress has been made towards final consideration of ratification. The Minister whom I represent is hopeful that ratification may still be possible in the not very distant future.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: MOOMBA TO STONY POINT OIL PIPELINE

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier today the Minister for National Development and Energy was asked a question about the industrial dispute concerning the workers on the Moomba to Stony Point pipeline. The rate of pay was quoted in that question. I now ask the Minister--
—Excessive rate of pay.

—We get an interjection from Senator Teague who says 'excessive rate of pay'. I think my interjection at the time was that the Government was paying lawyers $600 a day. I direct my question, without any assistance from Senator Teague, to the Minister for National Development and Energy. In view of the fact that these workers are working under some of the severest and harshest conditions that could ever be found, I ask the Minister when he consults with his colleague the Minister for Industrial Relations to get some information, also to ascertain the following: How many days do these people work every week? How many hours do they work each day? What are the highest and lowest temperatures these workers are required to work in? How does their present rate of pay compare with pay for comparable work in similar isolated and harsh conditions in other parts of Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will bring that question to the attention of my colleague the Minister for Industrial Relations and ask him to peruse it and consider a reply.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Martyr Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Attorney-General and arises as a result of a letter I received from a constituent. I draw the Attorney-General's attention to section 115 of the Constitution, which states:

QUESTION.PARA: A State shall not coin money, nor make anything but gold and silver coin a legal tender in payment of debts.
I ask-it is my constituent's question also: Does this mean that in order to satisfy debts to the Commonwealth, a State has to pay the Commonwealth in gold and silver coin?

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Martyr is very directly seeking a legal opinion. I suggest that he make the letter available along with any comments he may have on the matter. I will give it further consideration.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Does the Prime Minister support the undertaking given 12 days ago by the Treasurer-I use his words-to 'come clean with the Australian people' about the state of the economy? If so, will the Prime Minister repudiate the false assertion he made in his March electorate broadcast in which he stated: 'We have had economic growth at twice the average of other major industrialised countries in recent years'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware of the circumstances of either of the statements, that is, the statement by the Treasurer as referred to by Senator Walsh or the statement by the Prime Minister. What is clear is that, in fact, a number of Jeremiahs in recent weeks tried to suggest that all growth had stopped in Australia. They have been suitably put in their place by virtually every section of the media and by virtually every authoritative economist in this country. What has emerged is that, whilst there has been some slowing down of growth in Australia primarily due to the fact that there is a continuing recession overseas, the rate of investment in Australia is still very high indeed and the prospects of growth for Australia are still real. It is regrettable that due to recession we cannot, for example, go ahead with certain of our undertakings at this moment. One hopes that they are basically delayed and not finally abandoned. Nevertheless, the truth is that Australia has done well, and done well by comparison with other countries. I will have a look at both those statements. I will direct the attention of the Ministers concerned to the statements so that if they feel a necessity to reply they can do so.
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Will the Minister specify the duration of the period during which, allegedly, Australia did well compared with other countries?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will draw that question to the attention of the Treasurer and ask him to give chapter and verse on the matter.

—Can the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs ascertain whether there has been any authoritative study of the cost sensitivity on increased or maintained employment of wage increases in excess of productivity in such industries as clothing, footwear and textiles, automobiles and food processing and whether this has been extended to juvenile employees separately? If this type of survey has not been conducted will the Minister ask the Minister whom she represents to consider such a survey?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I will make inquiries in the relevant departments as to whether there is any basis for looking at employment as outlined in the question. If there is such a basis in either the Australian Bureau of Statistics or the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs I will see that the honourable senator is advised. If not, I will refer the question to the Minister to see what reaction he has to the suggestion implied within the question.

—My question to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence is in relation to the visit to Brisbane by the nuclear warship USS Truxtun. Is the Minister aware that, because of a dispute over compensation and time off, scientists from the Australian Atomic Energy Commission have threatened to ban any monitoring of radiation checks on the warship? If that is the case, will the Minister take steps to see that the USS Truxtun does not berth in Brisbane?
—I will refer that question to the Minister for Defence and ask him to provide an early answer.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: WESTERN AUSTRALIAN REPORT ON ABORIGINAL RESERVES

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, refers to a Western Australian Department for Community Welfare report on Aboriginal reserves. Is the Minister aware of this internal working document? If so, is he aware also that the Western Australian Chairman of the National Aboriginal Conference, Mr Riley, has been quoted as saying that it had been prepared without consultation with the NAC despite previous assurances by the Premier, Mr O'Connor, that consultations would take place? Is the Minister aware of a report in the West Australian that the document purports to recommend that the Government adopt a policy of closing reserves and has marked eight of the remaining Aboriginal reserves for closure as a matter of urgency? Is the Minister aware of Mr Riley's request that the Western Australian Government state clearly what its intentions are in relation to reserves, to ensure that Aboriginal interests, particularly in relation to land rights, are not being suppressed or denied? Will the Minister advise the Senate on action that he would be prepared to take to ensure that Aboriginal land rights are protected in Western Australia, or will he continue to abrogate his responsibilities to Aboriginals in Australia as he has done in the face of the Queensland Government 's Aboriginal land legislation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It scarcely seems necessary to respond to the rather gratuitous last part of the question, but I will try to respond to the main question asked by Senator Coleman concerning Aboriginal reserves around towns in Western Australia. I do not have any material on it, but I understand that there has been some continuing study of the appropriate way to provide housing for Aboriginals in Western Australia, particularly around some of the rural towns. It has been a policy to try to provide more housing and to upgrade the standard of housing available to Aboriginals. To this effect there has been a co- operative effort between the Department, the Aboriginal housing associations, the State through its State Housing Commission and housing for Aboriginals and, lately, the Aboriginal Development Commission.

ANSWER.PARA: As some of these housing developments have gone on, the need for camping reserves around some of the towns has altered and a number of reviews have been undertaken by the Western Australian Government. We have been kept aware of some of these reviews. I understand that the aim of the Western Australian Government is to try to make action on these reserves consequential upon the provision of housing through other avenues. Its objective is to get housing for Aboriginals which is appropriate to the town and to the population of Aboriginals which is available. I think it is a quite difficult area because I have spoken to a number of Aboriginal people in, for example, the eastern goldfields area who have indicated quite clearly that they do not want to move into conventional housing. Some of them have said that they have tried conventional housing and it does not suit them. For those people there is a need for some special arrangement which might be provided, for example, by an arrangement such as the one being undertaken in Kalgoorlie with the Parkeston development, which is now about to go ahead. So, provided we retain a flexibility of approach and a willingness to respond to a situation as we find it, I see nothing wrong with the Western Australian Department continuing to examine the need for housing and whether in some communities where adequate housing has been provided through alternative means it might give some consideration to closing down a reserve. But I must emphasise that the two sets of processes are interdependent and really consequential.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Communications whether it is a fact, as reported in the Australian Financial Review, that the Department of Finance and the Department of the Treasury have advised the Government that the cost of a domestic satellite could be twice as much as has been estimated. Would this put the cost of the satellite at some $600m? Is it also true that Telecom Australia has under consideration a proposal to change the system of charging for telephone calls from one based on distance of the call to one based on duration of the call? If these are the facts, why is the Government not prepared to wait for the completion in September of the current public inquiry into Telecom before making decisions which could radically affect telecommunications services in this country for decades to come?

—Some of the detailed parts of Senator Button's question will need to be referred to Mr Sinclair, the Minister whom I represent. I have had my attention drawn to the fact that articles appeared, I think, last Friday and also today in the Australian Financial Review making assertions of a cost escalation. I understand that Aussat Pty Ltd has advised the Minister that there has been remarkably little escalation in the anticipated cost of the satellite over the last two years and that, to that extent at least, the story may have used whatever information was available to draw a worst-scene scenario for the purposes of the newspaper story.

—Will the Minister for Health inform the Senate whether it is true that a decision has been made to implement a voluntary agreement with the tobacco industry to label cigarette packets with tar levels in ill-defined bands? Will the Minister agree that this form of labelling is confusing and does not give the smoking public clear information as to the content of different makes of cigarettes? As medical experts have recommended that cigarette smokers who cannot or will not give up smoking should change to cigarettes yielding the lowest possible amount of tar, will the Minister reconsider the decision and enforce a more appropriate method of labelling cigarette packets?

—The identification and promulgation of tar levels in cigarettes has been a matter of public concern for some years. I recall that a committee of the Senate was interested in this question and made some recommendations. I will have to get for Senator McIntosh details of exactly what is contained in the agreement and whether in fact there is a firm agreement between tobacco interests and government on this matter. I think Senator McIntosh is correct in that there is considerable benefit in consumers having the maximum available information so that they can make choices based on that information for their own purposes and for their own benefit. As to whether he is correct in what he says about the agreement that has been reached , I will have to get him more information.

—I was not going to ask a question but, in view of the flag- waving responses of some Ministers in relation to nuclear powered vessels, I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations whether he recalls that the successful visit of the United States of America's nuclear powered aircraft carrier Enterprise to Hobart in 1976 was possible only because of decisions taken by four small waterfront and maritime unions undertaking not to engage in the political boycott of the vessel as nationally advocated by the Seamen's Union of Australia and the Waterside Workers Federation of Australia. Is the Minister aware that the much-vaunted industrial legislation which was passed in the House of Representatives last week and which the Government hopes to force through the Senate this week will facilitate monopoly control by the Seamen's Union and the Waterside Workers Federation over the maritime and waterfront industries respectively? In view of the fact that had such monopoly control existed in 1976 the visit of the USS Enterprise could not have taken place, will the Government at this late stage consider withdrawing the legislation on the basis of the nation's security interests at this time?
—I think the short answer to the honourable senator's question is: No, the Government will not consider withdrawing the legislation at this late stage.
—Well, answer the question.

—That was the question. It is, of course, possible to point to areas where it has been to the advantage of the Australian community to have a multiplicity of small unions. It is also possible to point to examples of situations in which demarcation disputes have been the bane of the life of every Australian. I thought it was common ground in this place that this was one of the significant problems connected with Australian trade unions. In any event, I will refer the question to the Minister for Industrial Relations as the matter is primarily for his conduct. I will seek a formal reply, but I still think that the answer which I gave originally, namely, that the Government will not consider withdrawing the legislation, was the accurate one.

—I ask a supplementary question. I asked the Minister whether he was aware of the visit of the USS Enterprise in 1976 and whether he was aware of the fact that that visit was possible only because four small unions refused to engage in the political boycott which was nationally advocated by the Seamen' s Union and the Waterside Workers Federation. He has not answered those two questions, nor has he answered the question which related to the effect of the industrial legislation now before the Parliament passing over monopoly control to those unions which advocate a political boycott of vessels of a friendly power.

—Senator Harradine chooses to ask a question containing a whole series of questions rather than a single question. If he wishes to obtain detailed answers of that sort, I suggest that he place the question on notice.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 20 April and 22 April Senator McLaren asked me questions without notice concerning the Rundle project. I undertook to provide further information on two of his queries. The first concerned the current status and prospects of the Rundle project. The second concerned the time which had elapsed between my visit to the Rundle project and the public announcement by the Rundle partners following their reappraisal of the outcome of their project studies. With regard to the current status of the Rundle project, a formal joint venture agreement was signed by the partners in December 1981. This commits the Esso company to a minimum expenditure of $A30m over the next three years to carry out a technical and economic feasibility study of the project. Subject to Esso electing to continue, it is committed to a further minimum expenditure of $A20m over the following two years. The program of work to be undertaken by the partners-a substantial part of which will be carried out in Australia-includes geological studies, sampling, retort testing, engineering and economic evaluations. Any realistic assessment of the future prospects for the projects will have to await the outcome of the present work.

ANSWER.PARA: I visited the Rundle project on 18 February 1981, at which time I was provided with an up-to-date assessment of the project. The partners' announcement following their re-appraisal of the project was made on 6 April 1981. During the intervening period, as indicated in my reply to Senator Elstob on 7 April-I refer honourable senators to page 1138 of Hansard-the Government continually emphasised to Esso and the other partners the need for the results of their re- appraisal to be made and announced as quickly as possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier today Senator McIntosh asked me a question concerning the labelling of cigarette packets. I have been made aware that a Press release issued on 12 November last year by my predecessor and by the former Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs dealt directly with this matter and made it clear that the Government was responding directly to the recommendations on it by the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare. It indicated that the arrangements would be in place by August 1982 and that they would be reviewed after 12 months' operation. I will make a copy of the Press release available to Senator McIntosh in case any matters are not covered.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 22 April Senator Coleman asked me a question without notice concerning the continued publication of the Australian Prescriber. I undertook to try to obtain some further information. I am advised that the Australian Medical Publishing Co. recently wrote to my predecessor, the company being anxious to ensure that at least members of the Australian Medical Association, together with subscribers to the Medical Journal of Australia, should continue to receive accurate and unbiased material regarding pharmaceutical agents of the type provided to date in the Australian Prescriber . To this end the Australian Medical Publishing Co. has offered to use its best endeavours to publish, in association with the Medical Journal of Australia, the type of information appearing in the Australian Prescriber, the title of which it would require to pass to the company with the agreement of the Australian Government Publishing Service.

ANSWER.PARA: Under those arrangements, the Australian Prescriber could be expected to reach about 17,000 medical practitioners-as against the present publication list of about 23,400-about 10,000 pharmacists and about 4,000 dentists. The Australian Prescriber also goes to some undergraduates in these disciplines. I have asked my Department to investigate with the Australian Government Publishing Service whether agreement can be given to such an arrangement and to report to me on its implications. Only at that stage can a final decision be made on the matter .

PROCTEXT.PARA: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Gietzelt proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The inadequate leadership provided by the Government for nuclear disarmament.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by sessional order having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition again raises the question of the global arms race and the problems associated with nuclear weapons. Again we press the Government to take more steps to improve international affairs and to renounce the tensions that are obviously behind the arms build-up. For the first time in history mankind has the means of its own destruction. When I last spoke on this matter of the nuclear arms race I felt somewhat pessimistic about the opportunities that existed in this area and the chance for ordinary human beings to reverse the trends that existed then. My feelings were shared, I am sure, by my Australian Labor Party colleagues and my Australian Democrat colleagues in this place for at that time, in November, a new round of arms limitation talks was to begin in Geneva. The talks were to take the place of the abandoned and still not ratified SALT II negotiations.

SPEECH.PARA: Yet neither the United States of America nor the Soviet Union seemed prepared at the time to take real arms limitation and reduction seriously. The Soviets had deployed, and were continuing to deploy, triple warhead SS20 missiles aimed at targets in Western Europe and at the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation forces. The United States, buoyed mainly by this, was preparing to enter a new stage of the arms race by installing the Trident, the Cruise and the Pershing II missiles aimed at strategic targets in the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics. This was on top of the massive army of nuclear weapons each of the forces had stowed away ready for action in the depths of the Ural Mountains, on the salt flats of Utah, spread throughout Europe or beneath the surface of the Atlantic Ocean. To top if off we had the new Reagan Administration in America making aggressive noises and speculating about the possibilities of the so-called limited nuclear war. President Reagan himself made the now famous or, should I say, infamous remark reported by the New York Times:
. . . that he could see where you have the exchange of tactical (nuclear) weapons against troops in the field without it bringing either one of the major powers to pushing the button.

However, since that time I believe things have changed a great deal and in a qualitative way. We still have major international tensions, exacerbated currently, for example, in the Falkland Islands area. Of course, the massive nuclear armory has not gone away. But we now have the signs of a mass world-wide reaction, a popular movement, against the arms race. For example, in Western Europe, in the United States and even in parts of Eastern Europe hundreds of thousands of people have come out in the streets to protest against nuclear madness. They were joined on the streets between 4 and 7 April by over 100,000 Australian citizens in our major cities. No matter where people congregated, they expressed their views about the nuclear problems. In Sydney, where I marched, the spirit of the marchers was high and determined, despite the rain and despite the mammoth task of defeating the spread of nuclear weapons. I was proud to be marching with Anglican and Catholic bishops and with other important civic dignitaries.

These rallies now being held the world over aim to impact the United Nations Second Special Session on Disarmament. The rallies have brought together a huge number of disparate groups-a wide range of people including churchgoers, trade unionists, conservationists, members of ethnic groups and ordinary folk who, after all, make up the backbone of our society. Many of them had never thought before of becoming political or of taking part in a rally. But they feel, as indeed I know the Parliament should feel, the need to make the voice heard and to protest at the insanity and the sheer illogicality of a system that can destroy the world an infinite number of times over. On the occasion of that rally in Hyde Park, Sydney, author Patrick White summed up the feeling of a great number of the marchers when he quoted Mahatma Gandhi. He stated:

If I seem to take part in politics, it is only because politics encircles us today like the coil of a snake from which we cannot get out, no matter how much one tries. I wish therefore to wrestle with the snake . . .

These comments should be sobering to us as professional politicians. The decisions that those such as we are making about nuclear arms will affect the daily lives and perhaps even threaten the survival of millions and millions who are not really involved in politics as they understand it. When these people become involved, as they are now becoming involved, we professional politicians had better take notice. I believe that that is the purpose of the Australian Labor Party in raising this matter in the Senate today. Julie Flynn, writing in the National Times last week, remarked:
The anti-nuclear weapons movement has emerged so suddenly on the Australian political landscape that party tacticians on both sides have not yet had the chance to fully assess the consequences.

I believe she is right. Certainly, I have been a supporter of the peace and disarmament movement in recent years, but still the force of the concern of these recent protests surprised even me. It is now incumbent upon the Parliament and the Government to make its position clear and to act upon it. For the Labor Party's part, its position is clear and unequivocal. We believe that although Australia has no nuclear weapons, no one and no country is unaffected by the resurgent danger of nuclear war. Australia, because of its respected position as a middle power, its close ties with the United States and its vast resources of uranium, the base fuel of nuclear weaponry, is in a position whereby it can intervene in an international sense on the side of peace, disarmament and stability. But the position of the Liberal Party is less clear. We have in the past, for example, had some fine rhetoric from our Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, on this issue. For example, in his speech to the United Nations General Session on Disarmament in 1978 he said that there needed to be progress with the strategic arms limitations talks, that there was an urgent need for creation of a comprehensive nuclear test ban treaty, that measures were needed to prevent horizontal proliferation, that there was an urgent need for setting up regional zones of peace such as the Indian Ocean and that there was a pressing need to study the relationships between disarmament and the needs of the developing countries. They are fine sentiments, and the Labor Party supports such sentiments, but little has been done by the Prime Minister and the Government to support them since 1978. Mr Fraser's most notable contribution to the disarmament debate since then has been to unequivocally support the new United States arms build-up, as he did on his United States trip last year. Mr Fraser, speaking in December 1981, said:

Let me say at the outset that Australia is pleased indeed that President Reagan has embarked on the process of rebuilding United States defence forces. I take no pleasure or comfort from the criticisms which are sometimes levelled at the United States' policy in this area,--
Said Mr Fraser-
For peace can best be pursued from a position of strength. Indeed, it can sometimes only be pursued from a position of strength.

That quote came from the Canberra Times of 2 December last. In addition, this Government has eagerly sold our uranium without any real safeguards or guarantees as to what will happen to the reprocessed and enriched fuel. What does France do with it? What does the Soviet Union do with it? This is not the way, we submit, to actively promote the cause of peace and disarmament. It is little wonder then that no government members or senators have contributed to the public debate in the last few months on this question of nuclear war.

There are various ways to analyse the nuclear build-up. Most observers have used one or the other to suit their purposes. The most common analysis is that which seeks a balance of forces and, therefore, encourages mutual deterrence. The problem with this balance of forces analysis is that it can be misused, as I believe it is being misused by the Reagan Administration and by the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation. They have argued the Trident, Pershing and Cruise programs are necessary to draw even with the Soviet Union-that is the view that they express time and again-given its deployment of the SS20 missiles. They say that not to engage these new weapons would give the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics a tally of 300 missiles to nil in the nuclear scoreboard, as if they were talking about an ordinary little backyard war game. The Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Street, used exactly this logic in speaking in the House of Representatives last week when the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, Mr Lionel Bowen, raised matters similar to those which I am raising today.

There are two important matters which I wish to submit to the Senate concerning this sort of logic or, should I say, illogic. Firstly, most observers question the actual balance with which NATO comes up. For example, General Gert Bastian, the NATO general who resigned from his post in protest at the Western European contribution to the arms race and who visited Australia recently, had this to say:

Nobody denies that the deployment of SS20 missiles (which according to NATO standards is an overdue measure rather than one implying modernisation of special significance) will add to the disturbing Soviet capacity to pose a nuclear threat.

He went on to stress that NATO forces already have the appropriate systems available to counter the SS20 missiles. He said the new NATO moves 'would create a new and embarrassing situation for the Soviets, to the unilateral advantage of the US'. He is a gentleman who has been employed by his country, West Germany, and is a significant figure in NATO in Europe.

The second point I wish to make about this logic is that the USSR uses it too. We recognise this. I am sure honourable senators will recall receiving recently the glossy Soviet publication entitled 'Whence the Threat to Peace', which is full of pictures and diagrams showing the alleged superiority of the American weapons system. These graphs and diagrams are beside the point as we see it. They introduce the basic question of fear that exists between the two super- powers. The very logic of the arms race and the nuclear balance system ignores the fact that at a fraction of the armaments level of these countries we can still destroy civilisation. In cognisance of this fact, the respected Manchester Guardian editorialised along these lines:

Battle joined-the niceties would cease. With the atmosphere alive with radiation and communications put out of action, with supreme commanders taking split second decisions before they themselves were incinerated, no-one would ask whether the approaching missile was long-range or short-range.

It is the logic of the arms race which has led President Reagan to ask Congress for an extra $43.7 billion for military spending and which leads him to predict a United States military budget of $333 billion by 1985. It is this logic which leads the Soviet Union to burden its economy with an arms bill that will reach 15 per cent of its gross domestic product by 1985. It is this military logic which delivers profits in the order of $20 billion per year to the arms manufacturers.

The people of Australia-indeed, the people of the world-are justifiably scared by the prospect looming and they expect something from their political leaders- hence the raising of this matter of public importance today. There are signs in the United States that some political figures are responding to the chorus of popular opinion. Democrat and Republican senators and congressmen-140 of them all told in the United States legislatures-have sponsored resolutions for a United States-Soviet arms freeze. State legislatures in New York, Wisconsin, Kansas, Connecticut, Massachusetts and elsewhere have supported this call. Eminent figures, such as senior military men of the United States, the Soviet Union and England, have thrown their weight behind the campaign of international physicians for the prevention of war. I quote these examples:
Admiral Gayler, former Commander-in-Chief of US forces in the Pacific, won applause when he said-
At a conference recently-
it was nuclear weapons, not the Soviet Union or the United States, that were the enemy. 'We have got to join together and get rid of them,' . . .
Lord Carver, former Chief of the British Defence Staff, said he opposed the total abolition of nuclear weapons.
But he said: 'It would be criminally irresponsible for anyone to initiate nuclear war in the belief that it would remain limited.'
General Milstein, faculty head of the Soviet Academy of General Staff, said . . . 'Those who start a nuclear war in the hope of winning would start a holocaust and would perish in it,' he said.

The former United States Ambassador to the Soviet Union, George Kennan, former Secretary of State Vance and a former Secretary of Defence McNamara have all recently warned publicly of the dangers of nuclear arms proliferation. Our Government will have an opportunity in June next-six weeks away-to take a similar stand for peace. Let us hope that, when Mr Fraser and Mr Street speak to the United Nations Special Session on Disarmament, they do not take a pathetic and weak stance in support of Mr Reagan's militarism and the fear that that brings in the Soviet Union.

Mr Fraser has already disgraced himself and degraded Australia in this way with his statements in New York last year. It is our hope that Mr Fraser will respond this time to the views that exist in his country, to the sentiments that he expressed when he addressed the last United Nations conference on disarmament and take a stand for peace. Let us use our close and friendly relationships with the United States in a creative way, a way that will influence that Government towards finding a common thread that does exist in all humanity, and a way that will bring together the super-powers to take the turn towards world peace and away from nuclear war. We must recognise that we cannot allow a continuation of the build-up of the global arms race and of the obvious tensions and distrust that exist between nations, particularly the nations that are known as the super -powers. Let us hope that Mr Fraser will speak on behalf of all Australians when he goes to the United Nations this year and that he will use his influence and the influence of the Australian Parliament to bring about a change of direction in the United States and, in the process of taking that step, encourage the forces in the eastern part of the world, which have every reason to fear the possibilities of a nuclear holocaust. This is not asking too much of the Australian Government; this is not asking too much of our Prime Minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Sen The Hon D.B.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Country Party in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: — This afternoon we are debating a matter of public importance that alleges:

SPEECH.PARA: The inadequate leadership provided by the Government for nuclear disarmament.

I have listened with interest to Senator Gietzelt's contribution and I am basically in agreement with most of the things that he has said. Nobody in Australia would not accept that the intrusion of great nuclear power and capacity in the military world is a great threat to all people everywhere. The enormous problem is to find a proper and responsible basis on which it can be controlled and ultimately eradicated. In other words, how do we get both sides in this sort of circumstance to co-operate? That is the essential prelude to the ultimate solution of the problem. There is no question at all about the problem. There are all sorts of questions as to how we get the co-operation we need to solve it.

There must be recognition that there will be a reduction on a balanced scale until such time as perhaps, I hope, there will be no nuclear capacity. When I say 'on a balanced scale', I mean there is no ultimate solution of the problem by a unilateral reduction in one field or another, be it the Soviet Union or the United States of America. Indeed there is no evidence in the history of mankind that weakness has been a real contributor-indeed, a contributor at all-to avoiding armed conflict. Therefore, we shall have too look much further than that. We have only to go back to the 1939 circumstance when there was an extreme measure of weakness in the Western world in a military sense and in other senses . Its only contribution to the circumstances of those days was to be the prelude to perhaps the greatest holocaust to this point that man has known. We have to recognise the reality of the need for some form of balance of power in our search for ultimate peace in this field. Senator Gietzelt, in one of his quotations, said-I hope I quote him correctly, I only have a brief note-that nuclear weapons, not the United States or the Soviet Union, were the enemy.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was not my quote. It was Admiral Gayler's.

—The honourable senator quoted somebody and I omitted to note who he was. Of course there is absolutely no question that nuclear weapons, from a literal point of view, are the enemy. However, in reality it is the United States and the Soviet Union that control, develop and research them. Consequently the ultimate responsibility lies with those two powers.

SPEECH.PARA: The world today, for all sorts of reasons and not the least of which is the contribution of nuclear power, has shrunk to such a measure that we no longer look at borders and frontiers as being within vision. We are talking literally of hemispheres. We are hemispheres apart and yet significantly within range of each other. That only emphasises the need to come to a useful and proper solution to the problems that confront us. I suggest, briefly, that the Government has done a significant amount in ensuring a real consciousness, not only at home but also in our region and around the world, of the dangers and tragedies that are relevant to the development of nuclear weaponry. However, it appears extremely difficult to get into close contact with the Soviet Union. After all, on the best information that is available to me, the Soviet Union would appear to be the greatest nuclear power in the world today. If there are people in this country or outside it who have a closer understanding and even support for the socio-economic circumstances that are promoted by the Soviet Union within its boundaries and beyond, they have a massive responsibility to talk to the Soviet Union and to try to involve its citizens in the abhorrence of nuclear weaponry that we in the Western world must naturally have.

Reference was made at Question Time to the USS Truxtun which is a nuclear powered American warship, its proposed visit to Brisbane and the objections in some quarters to that sort of ship coming to an Australian port. Surely there has to be, as I said earlier, a measure of balance in the nuclear capacities of the major entities in the world if there is to be any hope of a reasonable and responsible solution. There has never been-I fear there never will be-a successful response from a side developing a significant weakness.

The Government has a well-established policy on nuclear disarmament. In fact, it has a well-established and a well-promoted policy on nuclear control in every field. It is significant and proper that Australia should have such policies as Australia is one of the world's greatest potential producers of uranium and, consequently, one of the greatest potential contributors to nuclear power in general. There is little doubt that in the longer term-it may well be a significant number of years-nuclear power in the commercial and economic field will have a very significant contribution to make to the development of many countries around the world and, in particular, to the developing countries.
