Consequently, it is important that we have a strong attitude to the control of nuclear power in all its areas and in all its characteristics. It is ridiculous and absurd to suggest that this country of all countries which, though not a nuclear power itself but which is so clearly involved with the basic materials that enable the generation of nuclear power, has no responsibility and no policies that are referable to the control of a source of energy and power which , in the wrong hands and with the wrong objectives, can be so incredibly damaging to most people around the world.

The ultimate goal of this Government-indeed, of the Australian people-is general and complete disarmament. That has been the goal of peoples around the world for many years. It is a goal that, regrettably, seems to be still some distance away. I believe-the Australian Government believes-the first step is to establish a real measure of control and then, finally, the demolition of military nuclear power. With that in view, the Government has sought, in every field possible, to establish balance and surveillance. It has sought balance in that whilst we approach the need to disarm from a point of view of nuclear armament, we will have, in that circumstance, a balance of power which will enable a certain recognition of reality and which will enable us to move through a proper measure of surveillance to a situation where, first, there will be a halting in the development of the nuclear military capacity and then, a downgrading of that capacity.

Senator Gietzelt mentioned, and I emphasise the fact, that in June and July this year, senior Government people such as the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street) and, in all probability, the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) will actively participate, as Australia always has done in matters of nuclear power control, in the United Nations Special Session on Disarmament. It is to be called together for the first time in four years since it last met in 1978. This session will be a total and comprehensive review of the problems that relate to nuclear armament around the world. There is no shadow of doubt that the Australian Government's presence there will be recognised by the strength with which it pushes the circumstances it will be promoting and the circumstances it has promoted over the years that are directed towards the control and ultimate demolition of nuclear military capacity. The Government has involved many non- government organisations. It has taken cognisance, naturally, of expressions of opinions in the Press, in the streets and all through the community in finally reaching a proposition to be put to this important discussion at a top level. This Government has tabled, amongst other things, every nuclear safeguard agreement that has come within its ken. Not only have they been tabled but also they have been debated. They are of extreme importance. The Government certainly would want it no other way than that they should be discussed in detail. That has been the consistent policy of the Government over the years that it has spent in office.

This type of matter has been discussed, as indeed, it should be, on frequent occasions. This could be the third or fourth time in six or seven months that it has been discussed in the Parliament. The Senate discussed, at some considerable length, only a month or six weeks ago, the question of the nuclear enrichment industry in this country. In the course of that discussion a whole range of controls were discussed and emphasised. Those controls, in the commercial field, are promoted with even greater emphasis in the field of military nuclear capacities. The curbing of nuclear weapons is a prime plank of Australia's disarmament policy. I imagine that in the view of all Australians it is a significant plank. As I said when I first rose to speak, there is no disagreement on the need to control and, finally, to dismantle nuclear military capacity. But there is a need to establish the best means of co-operation between the major nuclear powers. Of course, Australia is not a nuclear power, but certainly, it has a very clear recognition of the problems, the dangers and the disasters that relate to uncontrolled nuclear military power and, indeed, ultimately to any form of nuclear military power.

Australia supports, very strongly indeed, the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty, as a first step. It has been a supporter and a member of that organisation since its foundation. Membership of that Treaty, with all the requirements, guidelines and observations that are involved, is an absolutely essential pre-requisite to any form of Australian trade, let alone any concern with military nuclear circumstances. The nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty includes a full scope of the safeguards administered by the most effective body in the world today for this sort of thing, the International Atomic Energy Agency, over all nuclear installations in non-nuclear weapon states. I recall Australia's involvement with the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty as being one more piece of evidence of Australia's concern to control the enormous threat of nuclear power around the world. Australia, through its Government and I believe through the thoughts and deliberations of its people, seeks the conclusion of a comprehensive nuclear test ban treaty as a very significant contribution to the final restraint on nuclear disarmament. The comprehensive nuclear test ban treaty would help the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty very significantly. As a part of Government policy, we have opposed consistently the nuclear testing that has taken place from time to time by the French in parts of the South Pacific. This Government has consistently protested and opposed that sort of thing and seeks to destroy all possible chance of nuclear testing both in the atmosphere and without the atmosphere. Unfortunately, the French Government seeks to ignore, at this stage anyhow, the compulsory jurisdiction of the International Court of Justice. Consequently, we can make our protests known and we can make them forcefully, but to this point they seem to carry very little weight beyond that position. When we talk of Australian Government initiatives, it should be remembered that we co-sponsored the United Nations General Assembly motion in 1980 to establish a team to examine in-depth the problems relating to chemical warfare, those problems are almost as great and abhorrent-indeed, they are as great and abhorrent-as the threat of nuclear power to the countries of the world.

Finally those countries which have nuclear arsenals should reduce them. They must end nuclear testing in all environments and the Non-Proliferation Treaty must be strengthened and must grow. These are the basic projections of the Australian Government in this most important field.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sibraa Sen K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is most timely that the Senate should be debating this issue because in the middle of this year, which is in only a few weeks time, we will see the United Nations Special Session on Disarmament take place in New York. My colleague Mr Lionel Bowen said last week in the House of Representatives, when discussing this very same issue:

SPEECH.PARA: It is always left to the Opposition to raise in this Parliament any matter relating to disarmanent.

The disarmament movement has been sweeping rapidly throughout the world in the last few months. In Australia huge marches and demonstrations have taken place. Western Europe has witnessed gatherings the size of which has never been seen in that continent before. In Eastern Europe there is growing concern over the arms explosion with churches and other organisations strongly supporting the disarmament movement. In fact, it has caused some embarrassment to the leaders of East Germany. The church, not the government, has been at the forefront of these recent moves.

In Washington a freeze proposal sponsored by Senators Kennedy and Mark Hatfield won the support of 24 senators and 166 House of Representatives members. Senators Henry Jackson and John Warner have a proposal to build up United States nuclear forces as a prelude to negotiating balance reductions. It is important to look at the remarks made recently by Senator Jackson who is always considered to be a hawk on this issue. He said that President Reagan and the current Republican Administration in the United States of America have totally misjudged the mood of the American people in regard to nuclear disarmament. In March this year, 139 members of the United States Congress introduced a resolution in both Houses calling for a freeze in the level of stockpiles kept by the super-powers and urging them to pursue a complete halt to the nuclear weapons race. The question has to be asked: Why are so many people desperate to see the end of the arms race? For example, why would 40,000 people stand in the rain in Sydney a few Sundays ago to demonstrate for nuclear disarmament? I think the reason is that the present situation is frightening and the more the facts are publicised the more urgent the campaign will become.

I will quote some statistics which I consider are quite frightening when one looks at the situation of nuclear disarmament today. The total explosive power in the nuclear arsenals of the two super-powers is equivalent to about 16,000 million tonnes of TNT or about 1,250,000 Hiroshima bombs. The world's combined weapons of mass destruction are enough to kill every man, woman and child ten times over. On average, each of the major cities in the northern hemisphere is targetted by the equivalent of 2,000 Hiroshima bombs. Any honourable senator who has been to Hiroshima and seen the damage or anybody who has seen films or photos of what was done with one bomb would be staggered by those statistics.

The Trident submarines now being built by the United States are designed to carry a total of 192 warheads each with an explosive power equivalent to eight Hiroshima bombs; that is, each submarine will carry 192 bombs which, when multiplied by eight, gives a total of 1,536 Hiroshima bombs for each submarine. The Soviet Union is building similar machines of destruction, such as the Typhoon class submarines. These statistics surely must prove that nuclear war is unwinnable. Total world military expenditure is $US450,000m, whereas the annual spending on official development aid is $US20,000m and the cost of the World Health Organisation program to eradicate malaria is only $US450m.

When the President of the United States of America, Ronald Reagan, last year stated that the United States had accepted the concept of a limited, winnable nuclear war in Europe, the West Germans immediately demanded a full explanation and a rebuttal of that statement. I believe it was that statement that sent shock waves through Europe and precipitated the massive nuclear disarmament protest that we are seeing in Western Europe today. Unfortunately I believe that people are being slowly conditioned into believing that a limited and winnable nuclear war is a possibility. Once that concept is accepted, I foresee this as being just another step towards making nuclear war probable. On 21 October 1981, Senator Frank Church, who is the former chairman of the United States Senate Foreign Relations Committee, stated in Canberra:
There is no such thing as limited nuclear war. Any nuclear exchange would quickly escalate out of control. Any talk of limited nuclear war is unreal.

I completely agree with him. In a report published about the middle of last year our Office of National Assessments said that currently the world faces a 50 per cent chance of a nuclear conflict occurring. Some people will say that Australia is a long way from Europe and a long way from the scene of any possible nuclear war. I believe that since there can be no limited nuclear war, and there can be no winnable nuclear war as Senator Church said, Australia is as much involved as the Europeans. It takes only one miscalculation to bring about an all out nuclear war. It is also very important that we remember that 80 per cent of the world military expenditure at the moment is used in the conventional arms race. Conventional weapons have been used in all of the more than 100 armed conflicts since World War II, often with shocking effects on the civilian population. Arms technology has produced conventional weapons systems of unprecedented destructive power.

Earlier this year I visited the Lebanon. What we have there, by sheer weight and number of conventional arms, has turned that country into a nightmare. We have the Palestinians and the Syrian and Iraqi factions all controlling their own check-points and sections of the city of Beirut. At present they are all engaged in conflict amongst themselves. The Amal-Shia group, the Sunni Moslem Brotherhood and the Druze community in the Lebanon are all fighting the Palestine Liberation Organisation and sections of the Syrian Army, and occasionally all fighting amongst themselves. There is the Lebanese Resistance Movement, which is a Christian resistance movement. It has really turned its section of the country into a separate state. It now controls 15 per cent of the area of Lebanon and has about 50 per cent of the population in that area. Major Haadad has separate forces on the border of Israel. He has a so-called Christian militia. In fact, the enlisted men in his force are 70 per cent Shia Moslems. In the middle of this there is a Lebanese army that is completely powerless because in the country at the moment there are over 200 armed groups, all of them with sophisticated weapons, with missiles, with mines and with rocket launchers. The impression that I had when I was there was that every man over the age of 15 seemed to be carrying a Kalashnikov rifle or a machine-gun. This is a world gone mad. Also, in the Middle East, there is the current conflict between Iran and Iraq. The war continues with an horrific loss of life because the Soviet Union, the United States, Israel, the Arab world, the Europeans and even private arms dealers are continuing to supply weapons to both sides.

I mentioned these two instances because if there is a war in the Gulf like the conflict between Iran and Iraq or if there is a war in the Middle East triggered off by fighting in Lebanon this is of great strategic importance to the rest of the world. Such a war can involve the super-powers. It can escalate into a nuclear conflict purely because of the weight and the numbers of conventional arms that are in the region.

TALK.START.PARA: —We agree with that but what has that to do with inadequacies in the Government's leadership?

—I will get back to that. I was giving that as an example of how conventional arms can lead to a nuclear conflict. Another consequence of the arms build-up is the waste of millions of dollars that should be spent elsewhere . A report published last October by the United Nations pointed out that the Third World accounted for 75 per cent of all arms imports during the 1970s using precious and very limited foreign reserves to pay for them. Since 1945 collectively Third World countries have been spending an average of $19 billion each year on arms. I would like to give some further statistics on this subject. I therefore seek leave to have some of these statistics incorporated in Hansard. I believe that the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Sir John Carrick) has seen the statistics and will agree to their incorporation.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
The world currently spends a million dollars a minute on armaments-while one in three people in the world has no medical care, one in five is illiterate and one in seven is starving.

The Brandt report on the necessity for a new international economic order revealed that: 'For the price of one jet fighter ($20m) one could set up 40,000 village pharmacies'. It is sobering to reflect that Australia has contracted to spend about $3 billion on 75 new jet fighters.
A tank costs about $2m-this is equivalent to the cost of a couple of thousand class rooms, which would house about 500,000 children.
A US made Colt 45 automatic pistol costs $300-an African herdsman in the Chad would have to work almost a year in order to pay for one.
Half a percent of the spending on arms would pay for all the farm equipment needed to make food deficit countries self-sufficient by 1990.

It is estimated that deaths from smallpox exceeded 2 million every year before an attempt was made to eradicate the disease. The successful campaign from 1967 to 1977 cost around $300 million-less than 0.1% of what the world spends on arms in a year.

Malaria kills millions of people. About one million infants fall victim to it every year in Africa alone. To bring the disease under control would cost, it is estimated by the UN, $2,000m annually-less than what the world spends on arms in two days.
Half a million researchers i.e. more than 40% of all physics and engineering researchers in the world, are engaged in military research and development which amounts to $35-40,000m annually.

TALK.START.PARA: —Here in Australia we have to agree to give the prevention of nuclear war and universal nuclear disarmament the highest priorities on the agendas of foreign and security policies. Let us recognise:

SPEECH.PARA: Disarmament is a matter for political leadership, for political will and determination and common commitment and dedication.

These words, with which I agree completely, were spoken by the Prime Minister ( Mr Malcolm Fraser) at the special session of the UN General Assembly on Disarmament in 1978. It was a most promising speech but there has been no follow up by this Government. It is now quite clear that, despite those fine words four years ago, the Government has no clear or coherent policy on disarmament and arms control. We are a middle power but nonetheless we are influential enough and intelligent enough to have such a policy and to advocate it vigorously. At the 1978 UN special session on disarmament this Government listed key issues for the international disarmament agenda which included: Firstly, the need for greater progress in the American strategic arms limitations talks negotiations; secondly, creation of a comprehensive nuclear test ban treaty; thirdly, methods to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons to nations which do not have them; fourthly, the need to study the relationship between disarmament and the development needs of the poorer countries; and fifthly, creation of regional arms control arrangements, such as an Indian Ocean zone of peace.

We can compare these aims with what has been achieved since 1978. Firstly, Washington has failed to ratify SALT II and has virtually abandoned the progress that was made under the Carter Administration. Secondly, there has been no progress towards a comprehensive test ban treaty. Thirdly, far from preventing the spread of nuclear weapons among nations which do not already have them, current policies are encouraging such proliferation. Such developments as the introduction of B52 strategic bombers to Australian territory and, in the near future, to the Indian Ocean island of Diego Garcia are simply the latest examples of this policy. Fourthly, the need to study the relationship between disarmament and the development of the poorer countries is being neglected. Fifthly-I refer to the creation of regional arms control arrangements such as the Indian Ocean zone of peace; here at least there is some encouragement-there has been a recent American offer to make a formal proposal soon for a nuclear free zone in the Middle East. The Australian Labor Party has publicly welcomed that initiative as it is firmly committed to the establishment of nuclear free zones as one way towards preventing nuclear war and achieving nuclear disarmament. Yet, to the best of my knowledge, this important United States proposal drew no public support from the Australian Government.

I propose that Australia seek official or unofficial membership of the Independent Commission on Disarmament and Security Issues which is headed by Olaf Palme, the former Prime Minister of Sweden. Its membership includes many distinguished persons from the East and the West and the Third World. We ought to be a member of that commission. It is working to support and publicise the UN Special Session on Disarmament. I believe that the Australian Government has no clear or comprehensive policy on disarmament. Moreover, this Government does not take every opportunity to advocate disarmament or actively encourage public participation in the disarmament movement. It was a great shame that last year's Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting in Melbourne failed to take advantage of the impressive gathering of world leaders to make a strong statement on disarmament. I hope that as a result of this matter of public importance proposed by the Opposition today the Government will show the leadership that is needed on this vital issue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate this afternoon is debating a matter of public importance from Senator Gietzelt which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The inadequate leadership provided by the Government for nuclear disarmament.

The proposition is absolutely untrue. If the proposal read that the Opposition complimented the Government on the leadership it has provided towards nuclear disarmament it would be another matter with which we could agree with the Opposition. But there is no case at all to make that the Government has not given the most effective leadership it can on this most difficult of questions. As Senator Scott said there is universal acceptance of the goal that we have to reduce nuclear disarmaments as much as possible. That implies having some degree of control over the nuclear armament business and moving on from there at a later stage to general disarmament. The Government supports those goals unequivocally.

The point of difference between the Government and the Opposition is in the fact that the Government understands the very great complexities of the issues that are involved in this move; the Opposition simply does not appreciate what is involved here. It has a simplistic view on this matter. I say this with no disrespect. It is a view that members of the Opposition have on most of the complex issues that face Australia today. As an example of the complexities involved in this matter I quote a few words from a speech by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) to a special session of the United Nations General Assembly in June 1978 which illustrates very well the complexities of what is involved. The Prime Minister said:

One fact is certain-the forces militating against arms control are powerful. We cannot hope to begin to dismantle the world's military apparatus unless we address our minds to the causes which nourish and sustain it: the motion that increased military spending inevitably provides greater national security regardless of the objective facts, the narrow self-interest and ambition which nations can pursue-reckless of the tension and conflict which this may generate; the quest for national status which still motivates the actions of many states; attempts to exploit the weaknesses of smaller states; the attempt to expand a nation's influence over other states, under the cloak of ideology-regardless of damaging competition with other powers which results.

The Prime Minister listed just a few of the many factors involved in the nuclear armament business, a few of the reasons why nations seek nuclear arms for their own protection. The difficulties here are quite enormous. They are fully appreciated by this Government as nations have tried for years and years to make progress down this path to goals which we all support. The Government has supported every international forum and, more importantly, the Government is an active member of every international forum, notably, of course, the Committee on Disarmament which is a negotiating body, not a talking body, with 40 members on it. Any discussions on disarmament, nuclear disarmament in particular, has to recognise that it is an international matter; it is not a provincial matter.

One of the bodies of which the Government has been a supporter and a member is the United Nations Special Session on Disarmament. On 5 June 1978 the Prime Minister addressed the General Assembly. I quoted from his speech earlier. The Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Street, will lead the Australian delegation in June and July of this year to the second United Nations conference where again, as forcefully as it can, the Australian delegation will put forward the Governments position that nuclear disarmament should proceed.

Australia is a signatory to the Treaty on Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons, the basic treaty concerning and controlling the spread of nuclear materials in this world. I say in passing that our credentials in that Treaty are second to none. Other signatories to that Treaty have sold nuclear materials-uranium-to countries such as Argentina. Australia scrupulously observes both the spirit and the intent of that Treaty and will continue to do so. Finally, I mention the comprehensive test ban, which has our unambiguous support, as witnessed by the Opposition we have expressed to the French testing in the Pacific. Those are facts. They are not suppositions. They are not hypothetical cases. The support for the Committee on Disarmament, the United Nations Special Session on Disarmament in 1978, the coming United Nations Special Session on Disarmament, the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty and the comprehensive test ban all bear witness to our sincerity and our determination to prosecute this aim.

I listened with interest to Senator Gietzelt and Senator Sibraa. Senator Gietzelt, as usual, was more sympathetic to the Russian point of view than he was to the American point of view. I was rather interested to hear him claim that the introduction of SS20 missiles by the Russians was really to catch up with the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation position. I think that is a military appreciation which will find no support whatsoever in any Western military circles. Senator Sibraa gave us a most interesting talk about Lebanon and Kalashnikov rifles, but for about 12 minutes of his talk he failed to address the title to which he was speaking. The general drift of the Opposition's argument is that the Government has done nothing. The treaties I have listed and the committees of which we are an active member give the lie to that allegation. I noticed that in the other place the Australian Labor Party is keen to say that we only sell uranium for cash where we can get it. Again, that is not true because we sell only to countries that are signatories to the Non-Proliferation Treaty.

In dealing with this most complex problem we have to realise Australia's position. We are not the prime and leading actors on the world stage. Australia is a very small country militarily. We do not have much international clout in the military field. If we were either the United States of America or the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics our position would be quite different, but we are not. We are only one voice among many in the community of nations. Secondly, we are not a nuclear power. Furthermore, as a signatory to the Nuclear Non- Proliferation Treaty, we cannot be. The only resources Australia has in the international forum are the resources of the power of reason. To be effective in reasoning we must take into account the realities of the world situation as it is today. We have to start with the world as it is. We cannot start with a hypothetical ideal world.

We support the concept of disarmament-not just nuclear disarmament. But we can only support that concept provided it is universal because we know that if it is not universal we cannot have the support which we need of the other nations to bring it about. We are faced with this dreadful dilemma when we come to the subject of disarmament because disarmament simply cannot work without trust between nations. Yet, tragically, if that trust had existed in the first place there would have been no need at all for nations to arm themselves against their neighbours. So we start with a position where there is no trust-or very limited trust-in this world. We have to build that trust as the first step down our path towards any effective nuclear disarmament program.

While on the subject of mistrust, one must look at the actions taken by the USSR and the momentum which it has attained in the last 10 years and with which it is still proceeding in arms acquisitions. For the last decade the USSR has grossly overspent on its defence requirements. Defence spending is estimated to be at least 13 per cent of its gross domestic product. Russia has a huge arsenal of SS17, SS18 and SS19 intercontinental ballistic missiles. It has the Backfire bomber and the Typhoon submarines, as Senator Sibraa mentioned, are coming on- stream. Above all, Russia has the SS20 missiles, which have a range of 4,000 kilometres and can hazard and bring under attack the whole of Western Europe-the whole of the NATO mass.

What has Russia done? It has proceeded to arm itself to the teeth. At present it enjoys conventional arms superiority in the NATO theatre, yet it has gone on accelerating its theatre advantage with respect to both nuclear and conventional weapons. it has made no effective recognition of the protest movement towards disarmament in Western Europe. All it has said it will do is pull out its SS20 missiles west of the Urals. That is no concession at all because the range of those weapons is such that from east of the Urals they can bring the whole of the NATO countries under attack. So any unilateral move by Western nuclear powers would be absolutely untenable. Acceptance of any of the propositions that a freeze be introduced at present would merely perpetuate the ascendancy in nuclear weapons that the USSR has gained over the last 10 years. If we introduced a freeze at the point where the USSR has this ascendancy we would only build instability into the relationships between the super-powers.
The second point, after developing trust, is to get parity between the nuclear powers as a pre-requisite for some agreed disarmament. That is an enormously difficult proposition.

The major problem is that since the Second World War peace has been achieved by the existence of nuclear deterrent. Because we have a nuclear deterrent the super-powers have always built and accelerated their capacity in this direction. It has had a positive side because we have had peace in Europe for 37 years, despite periods of intense political tensions. That does not mean, of course, that peace can be achieved only by nuclear deterrents. But the reality is that the nuclear deterrent doctrine is the instrument of peace at present and it will take some time, some care, and a great deal of patience to move away from that doctrine and have it accepted by other nations that there are other ways of determining peace.

I would like to move to another area that is very important to Australia and it is an area where Australia's lesser powers can have some influence. I refer to the spread or the horizontal proliferation of nuclear arms to the second line or Third World countries. The Non-Proliferation Treaty has been fully supported by Australia and the dangers posed by the spread of nuclear weapons-a horizontal proliferation-are, in many ways greater threats to the world than those coming from a conflict between the two super-powers. Just as a matter of conjecture we could say that Israel, India, Pakistan, Libya, South Africa and possibly, the Argentine, could all have nuclear weapons at present. This is a very dangerous situation because these types of countries lack sophistication in their intelligence gathering capacities, they lack control, both politically and militarily, of the forces in the country and, very frequently, their contiguous countries have been rivals or enemies for centuries. Added to this local rivalry we often have the fact that they are centres of great power struggles, such as in the Middle East. It is possible that a conflict between two neighbouring states could involve the major powers with catastrophic influences for all of us . Australia, with its clear support of the Treaty on the Non-proliferation of Nuclear Weapons and its influence in international forums has played a very effective part in trying to control this lateral spread of nuclear arms. Australia's position is one of the support for the ultimate goal of general and complete disarmament and a negotiation of balanced and verifiable means of arms control. I move:
That the business of the day be called on.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lajovic Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, I present the 196th Report of the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The 196th Report on the Curatorial and Conservation Functions of the Australian War Memorial breaks new ground for the Committee. Rarely has such a topic been considered by this or any other committee of the Parliament. Curatorial and conservation functions relate to the capacity of the Australian War Memorial to exhibit, maintain, catalogue and restore its collection. In his report to Parliament of 30 March 1981, the Auditor-General highlighted the parlous state of the collection of the Memorial and the administrative difficulties that were contributing to it. The Committee's inquiry has fully substantiated his report.

SPEECH.PARA: In historical terms, the worth of the collection to this nation is immeasurable . In monetary terms, it has been valued at over $100m. Because of past neglect, parts of the collection are at risk. Already many assets have been lost, including 17 vintage aeroplanes now worth over $100,000 each. The Memorial estimates that it will take at least 400 working years of conservation to restore the existing collection fully. The problem however does not end at the War Memorial. The Committee found that other institutions within the National Collection, such as the National Library of Australia and the Australian Archives, also face heavy conservation backlogs. A similar situation will arise in the case of the Museum of Australia unless early action is taken to re-house and store its existing collection in an appropriate manner. These backlogs have arisen for a number of reasons. Firstly, there has been a lack of awareness by those who have been responsible for the conservation and maintenance of the collection in the past. This 'unwitting neglect', as it has been described, has been an outcome of complacency engendered by the fact that the Memorial attracts a high proportion of those who visit Canberra. This high attendance has apparently been interpreted as an indication that further upgrading of the display or condition of the collection was unnecessary. Secondly, the need to conserve all collections has only recently been realised by most museums and government institutions. Consequently, there is an insufficient number of suitably trained personnel on whom to draw and inadequate funds to employ those experts who are available.

Our Committee believes that there has been an inequitable sharing of resources amongst institutions responsible for the National Collection; for example. The Australian National Gallery, in contrast to the War Memorial, is well endowed. Since the completion of the inquiry, the Public Service Board has advised the Committee that some action in line with our recommendations regarding staff ceilings and salaries at the War Memorial has already been implemented. We hope that this trend will continue. The Committee's recommendations are numerous. In essence they involve the following proposals: A greater role for the Department of Home Affairs and Environment in co-ordinating resources within the institutions responsible for the National Collection; personnel career planning for curators and conservators within government employment which would involve revision of the salary structure and classifications; staff ceilings for the Australian War Memorial to be at least on a par with the Australian National Gallery; and introduction or extension of corporate planning techniques, disaster planning procedures, internal auditing, conservation data bases and automatic data processes inventory control systems within all institutions housing the National Collection, especially the Australian War Memorial.

The Committee wishes to make the public and the Government aware that conservation is not the problem only of the institutions. Preventive conservation methods such as the use of long-life inks, typewriter ribbons, paper, et cetera-must be encouraged if further compounding of the conservation crisis is to be prevented. With the exception of the segment housed in the National Gallery, a conservation crisis does exist within the national collection. This is exemplified by the poor and threatened condition of the Australian War Memorial collection. We acknowledge that only a certain amount of the resources of the national purse can be allocated to solving the problem. It is a problem that must be tackled now and we call for a review of the allocation of these resources and improved management approaches within the institutions in an attempt to overhaul these serious conservation backlogs.

Under the user pays principle the question of admission charges was canvassed. However, while the Committee makes no firm recommendation on this issue we are concerned that if the Memorial does not fully utilise its revenue raising potential its current position as the poor relation within the National Collection may be exacerbated. The need for a high standard of conservation for the National Collection is essential. The threat to these unique repositories of Australian history and traditions demands the attention of Parliament. We appear to be witnessing the unmaking of Australian history. That, my Committee believes , will concern all members of the Parliament as well as the citizens whom we represent. I commend the report to honourable senators.

CONCILIATION AND ARBITRATION AMENDMENT BILL 1982

Mr President, in his ministerial statement on 'Wage Determination and Industrial Relations' on 16 February the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner) informed Parliament that he intended to introduce a number of legislative initiatives. I now present a Bill to the Senate about matters then foreshadowed. The Bill contains a number of elements but its philosophy can be distilled to three main themes:
protection of the rights of the individual;
to provide a better balance in the powers, rights and duties of employers and empoyees; and

to open the door to movement from within the work-force so that present union rigidities and monopolies are loosened and structures created which are more suited to a modern economy and representative negotiations between employers and employees.
Let me develop these themes and outline to the Senate how the Bill will give effect to the Goverment's aims.

Fundamental to the Government's approach is its belief that the expression and pursuit of democratic freedoms, including the rights of association and the withholding of labour, and the operation of free institutions, such as trade unions, cannot survive in the absence of law. Our industrial relations system assists in setting a base from which behaviour patterns can develop which are acceptable to the majority and which in turn foster a strong, progressive nation .

The notion that for some reason unions are so different that they and the conduct of their members should stand beyond the law is untenable and at the root of much of the industrial trouble Australia has experienced in recent years .
There are constitutional limits on the Commonwealth's industrial relations powers although there may be more room to make new laws than we have given the Constitution credit for in the past.
In the life of this Government we have already acted within our legislative power to protect the public interest.

We have legislated to ensure that rank and file union members have a greater say in union affairs and, to this end, are provided with full information on their union's financial affairs. We have strengthened the provisions for secret ballots. We have provided a method of seeking rapid deregistration where a union threatens the safety, health or welfare of the public.
We have also strengthened our own hand in dealing with unreasonable industrial action by employees of the Commonwealth.

The Government is, by this Bill, proposing legislation in support of the principle of voluntary unionism and the restructuring of unions away from a craft and occupational basis. We are also legislating to give employers the automatic right to stand down employees who cannot be usefully employed as a result of industrial action.
These proposals reflect so far as is reasonable the points raised by the ACTU and employer representatives at two meetings of the National Labour Consultative Council.
Voluntary Unionism

Legislation for voluntary unionism is a firm policy of the Government parties. In our liberal democratic society, individuals should have the right to decide whether or not they want to join a union. If they do not they should be protected by the law. This Bill will give them that protection. If they do so, they are encouraged to play a responsible and active part in their union's affairs.
Mr President, nobody should be under any pressure to join a trade union. There should be a completely free choice of whether to join or not to join a union.

This is a central feature of the Bill now before the Senate. It introduces to the principal Act this right of choice. It removes from the jurisdiction of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission the power to grant preference to unionists and it provides avenues of redress against both employers and unions in the event of victimisation of individuals who do not want to join a union.
The objects of the Act will be amended to positively declare the principle of voluntary unionism.
By the Bill, an employer or a union will be prohibited from disadvantaging, to use a general description, an employee or prospective employee not wishing to belong to a union.
A person will be able to defend their freedom of choice by a right to seek compensation in the Federal Court for loss or damage suffered as a result of action taken to force them to join a union.

We are providing that, where an employer is the subject of compensation proceedings and considers that a union's conduct has induced the employer to take the action for which he is being proceeded against, the union may be joined as a party to those proceedings. It would then be open to the Court to give judgment against the union instead of the employer or partly against the union and partly against the employer. It may be of interest to honourable senators to note that this is consistent with provisions passed recently in the United Kingdom Parliament.
Stand-downs
I now turn to the provisions in the Bill relating to stand-downs.

Increasingly, strikes and bans from plant to plant or industrial action by small key groups of workers have been used to put intense economic pressure on a single employer, a whole industry or the whole community.

In circumstances of this character, an employer simply has no work for his employees. The employer's capacity to resist a strike or other industrial action is reduced to nothing, because the wages bill goes on running. Protection is needed in that situation and the Government intends to provide it.

If unions are to have, as a basic principle, the 'right to strike' then it is surely not unreasonable for employers to have at their individual disposal, the right to protect their commercial interests in circumstances where they are put at risk by union action.

Strikes, and other forms of industrial action, do not simply affect the businesses of those directly subject to that action. They effect also other businesses and other employees dependent upon the goods and services of the business being disrupted. As the community has come to appreciate to its cost and often to its despair, the industrial action in one place ripples widely throughout society.

The law has long recognised, by awards of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, that workers who are not on strike but who cannot be usefully employed because of action elsewhere, may be stood-down without pay.

But the processes to be followed are, in many instances, cumbersome and involve delays and the terms of the stand-down award may not in the end be commensurate with the industrial pressure being exerted leaving the employer lamenting that the law and the circumstances leave him defenceless.

Using a blend of constitutional powers, the Bill extends to employers the direct right-and I emphasise that-to stand-down employees who cannot be usefully employed because of industrial action. The decision to stand-down will be the decision of the employer according to the circumstances with which he is faced.

There may be circumstances in which employers would wish to use the processes available presently through the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. The Bill gives employers the choice between doing that or using the new provisions. However, the Commission will not be able to limit the rights of employers under these new provisions.
Industry Unions
I now turn to the proposals relating to industry unions.
There is a widely held community view that the craft system of union organisation is increasingly creating difficulties for the sensible operation of industrial relations.

Craft and conglomerate unionism has resulted in a situation where most industries and many enterprises face a multiplicity of unions. Union amalgamation of itself is not sufficient to improve this situation substantially .

Much of the past discussion about amalgamation of unions failed to distinguish between the objective of allowing the creation of industry unions and amalgamations which create bigger conglomerate craft unions, the membership of which straddles a number of industries. Encouragement of the development of unions along these lines will not, in the Government's view, assist in reducing the level of industrial disputes to any significant degree. The record of the AMWSU is testimony to that.
The Government's long-standing objective, expressed in our Industrial Relations Platform, is the encouragement of industry based unions. It is also the objective of the Labor Party and the ACTU.
This legislation faces up to the need for change by providing a legislative framework which will facilitate the restructuring of unions into fewer industry- based organizations.
The Government is well aware that the development of industry based unions will not be an easy process or one that will take place overnight. However, a start has to be made.
Within the trade union movement itself, and amongst employers there is evidence of interest in some industries that unions should be industry based.

The Bill defines an industry for the purpose of registration of an industry union as the business, trade, manufacture, undertaking or calling of employers. It is proposed to leave to regulations the prescription of the classes of industry for which a union can be formed to enable discussions to be held with the ACTU and employers as the process of change is initiated. In this way the development of industry unions can occur in consultation with unions and employers directly involved and the peak employer and union bodies.

To obtain registration an association of employees will need to satisfy the Registrar that the members are employed in a single industry and that they constitute a substantial majority of the total number of persons employed in that industry.

The Bill also provides for regulations to be made to allow for a secret ballot to be held of employees in an industry to test whether a substantial majority wish to form or join an association seeking registration as an industry union.

The Government is also making provision for an existing union to become an industry union by the process of changing its rules to enable the absorption of employees who would not otherwise be eligible to become members. However, an existing organization, seeking to establish itself on an industry basis, will have to satisfy the Industrial Registrar that the rule changes are authentic and have been democratically endorsed within the organization.
Where an amalgamation of unions would result in the formation of an industry union, special conditions will apply to facilitate that amalgamation.

The present requirement that in a ballot to approve an amalgamation at least one half of the persons on the roll of voters must vote and, of those voting formally, more than one half must vote in favour of the amalgamation, will be relaxed. Where an amalgamation would result in the formation of an industry union (and only that in that case), not less than one quarter of the persons on the roll of voters will need to vote, and of those voting formally more than one half must vote in favour of the amalgamation.
This particular provision is drawn from earlier recommendations made to me by the National Labour Consultative Council about the amalgamation processes of the Act.

These provisions of the Bill are seen by the Government as a first step in the process of encouraging the formation of industry unions. We will naturally be watching their application and development closely and be ready to adapt or change them in the light of experience.

Mr President, the Government has not included in this Bill any provision for the formation of enterprise unions. The Government's proposals in this area are being further developed in consultation with employer and union groups.
Other Provisions of the Bill

There will continue to be, unless the situation is remedied, problems in relation to the de-registration of organizations under both the State and Commonwealth systems. This Bill is intended to cover the situation where a union tries to play off one industrial relations system against another in circumstances where a State union is deregistered in its own jurisdiction. A State union will not be able to move into the Federal jurisdiction to avoid the consequences of its industrial misbehaviour in a State jurisdiction and the discipline of that jurisdiction.

These proposals have been introduced at the request of the Western Australian Government. To operate, this part of the Bill requires reciprocal State legislation. The Minister will be raising this with his colleagues, the State Ministers for Labour.

Amendments are made by this Bill to provide for greater certainty in the administration of unions where casual vacancies arise. There are situations in which it may be desirable for a vacancy to be filled by appointment, rather than by election. The amendment will permit a casual vacancy to be filled by appointment, provided that the unexpired portion of the term of office is less than 12 months. Special provision is made in the case of appointment to a casual vacancy in an electoral college.
At present, the rules of an organisation do not permit a person to be elected to hold an office for a period exceeding 4 years, without being re-elected.
The Government has accepted representations from the ACTU, through the National Labour Consultative Council, that this requirement is unduly harsh when officers are approaching retiring age.

The Bill, therefore, proposes that the rules of an organisation may permit the holder of a full time office, who is due to retire within a period of 12 months after the expiration of the period for which he was elected, to remain in office until he retires.

Consistent with what I have said earlier about encouraging democratic control of organisations registered under the Act, the Government has decided to enlarge the scope for financial assistance to parties to proceedings in the Federal Court in cases involving that principle. The opportunity has been taken of consolidating the financial assistance provisions of the Act.

The Bill also introduces new procedural arrangements to simplify the application in the Territories of variations to common rules made in the Commission. These arise from discussion of this matter in the National Labour Consultative Council.

Mr President, these principal legislative initiatives which I bring before the Senate, voluntary unionism, an employer's statutory right of stand-down and the formation of industry unions-are the start of a program of reform of the Australian industrial relations system. There is much to be done. As the Minister for Industrial Relations said in his Ministerial Statement on 16 February last, ultimately reform of industrial relations in Australia needs to go further than simplifying and restructuring what we now have.
It is as challenging a cause as any which faces Australia.

Mr President, this Bill tackles three principal areas of current interest. It is based on the philosophy, policies and objectives of the Government parties. The Bill confronts no-one. It looks to strengthening the rights of individuals, bringing into balance the rights of unions and employers and opens the doors to the restructuring of union organization in this country.
I therefore commend the Bill to the Senate.
COMMONWEALTH EMPLOYEES (VOLUNTARY MEMBERSHIP OF UNIONS) BILL 1982

This is a short Bill, Mr President, and a simple one. It follows from what is provided in the Conciliation and Arbitration Bill, to give effect to the Government's intentions about the voluntary nature of union membership and preference to unionism.
The Bill declares void any award determination or agreement which makes provision relating to the employment of persons by reference to membership of an association.
It withdraws powers to make provision for preference by reference to membership of an association.
It is therefore designed to put into effect in the area of Commonwealth Government employment the principles proposed in the Conciliation and Arbitration Bill.
Mr President, I commend the Bill to the Senate.

Honourable senators will be aware that this item relates to the consideration of committee reports. It is an attempt by the Standing Orders Committee to suggest to the Senate that it may wish to provide a mechanism whereby committee reports can be considered on a regular basis. It does not alter, of course, the capacity for the Senate to do during debate on General Business items what it has done for years. But it will provide an extra amount of time on a regular basis each week for committee reports to be debated.

The Standing Order provides that an hour be set aside on the Thursday of each week and that there be limited time for each speaker so that up to six speakers might take part in the debate. An attempt has been made by the Standing Orders Committee-I reiterate that I am speaking in this debate as a member of the Standing Orders Committee and as a senator, not on behalf of the Government, in what is a senators' debate-to ensure that should there be no committee reports, there is a capacity for some flexibility for using that hour to consider committee reports that were previously brought up. It is a genuine attempt by the Standing Orders Committee to provide for the Senate an extra mechanism. I think it was tried once in the past and it was not unsuccessful. It is considered to be an appropriate moment to reconsider the proposal.

No Senator shall speak for more than thirty minutes in any debate in the Senate . Any Senator may move that the time limit of thirty minutes be extended for fifteen minutes; such motion shall forthwith be put without debate.

The Standing Orders Committee, as honourable senators know, consists of senators representing each group within the Senate. It has for some time been looking at ways in which the proceedings of the Senate might be made more effective to meet the requirements of honourable senators. The recommendations which have come forward are recommendations from the Standing Orders Committee. Again, they are not Government recommendations. They have been put forward by senators representing the Australian Labor Party, the Liberal and National Country Parties and the Australian Democrats. The recommendations include proposals that the time limit on speeches on non-broadcast days be 30 minutes, as the time limit is now on broadcast days. I offer a personal opinion that some of the most effective speeches we hear are on broadcast days. I can see no limitation of honourable senators' rights. There is nothing to stop any honourable senator seeking the leave of the Senate in a particular situation, should it arise and should a particular matter of importance come up. We are also seeking to look at a special limit of 15 minutes on the speaking time in debates on the first readings of Bills which the Senate may not amend. This does not carry with it any limitation on the capacity to debate matters during the first readings of these Bills, nor does it put a time limit on the debate itself. It merely suggests that in order to allow more honourable senators to participate in the debates and to give honourable senators a chance to play a fuller role in the Senate, the 15 minute limit may not be inappropriate. I commend the proposed amendment to the Standing Order to the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I oppose this proposed new sessional order. When I first became a member of this chamber many honourable senators, when they spoke, took the maximum time allowed them. I believe one of the reasons the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) and those honourable senators who are members of the Standing Orders Committee who advocated this change did not bring forward the actual average duration of speeches in this place today is that the production of those figures would demonstrate that in the vast majority of cases speeches in fact last for less than half an hour.

SPEECH.PARA: It is said that this sessional order will improve the proceedings of the Senate . I do not believe we have had any evidence that that is in fact so. It is certainly true that on the odd occasion an honourable senator in this place has spoken for more than half an hour or even for more than an hour. At times I have been as annoyed as anyone else about the individual cases. I repeat: In the vast majority of cases speeches in fact are less than half an hour. In those circumstances it is very difficult at times for honourable senators to cover the subject matter in half an hour and they frequently need more than half an hour.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too will outline my opposition to the changes proposed in the report of the Standing Orders Committee. I do not remember the occasion particularly because the speech took so long, except that former Senator McAuliffe was wanting to follow in the debate and was getting a little itchy waiting for the whole hour to go so that he could have his turn. I remember that the particular senator, who may now remember the occasion I refer to, mentioned that he was in London and had had a good meal of bangers and mash. The other occasion I remember was more recent when a very complex matter was debated. SPEECH.PARA: No Senator shall speak for more than one hour in any debate in the Senate, except that in the debate on the Address-in-Reply, or on the first reading of a Bill which the Senate may not amend, or in moving the second reading of a Bill, he shall be at liberty to speak for one hour and a half.
That is what the Standing Order stated prior to the amendment in 1975. Then it went on:
Any Senator may move that the limit of one hour or of one hour and a half may be extended for thirty minutes; such motion shall forthwith be put without debate:

TALK.START.PARA: —The speeches are getting better all the time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to enter into this debate very briefly-largely for practice, I suppose. I wish to support the report of the Standing Orders Committee of which I am a member. I think it would be hurtful indeed if, after all our deliberations on this point, the matter were to be rejected on the basis of arguments which perhaps did not fully take account of the issues which concerned the Standing Orders Committee. Some of my colleagues spoke at great length about the rights of honourable senators. Of course we all have very substantial rights by virtue of the fact that we are senators-rights which most members of the public do not have and which I think the public is very much aware of in relation to politicians. With respect, the question is not really one of rights. If one claims that it is an inalienable right of an honourable senator to speak as long as he or she wishes, why does one choose an hour rather than two hours?

SPEECH.PARA: What one has to do-the Standing Orders Committee was concerned about this aspect-is to moderate rights in order that the participation of all honourable senators can be assured as far as possible. It is not a question of individual rights; it is a question of the rights of honourable senators as a collective group. Each honourable senator should have an opportunity to speak in a debate. Only a finite amount of time is available. If the rights of a particular honourable senator are considered to be so important that he or she should speak for an hour, that is a delimitation of the rights of other honourable senators. That is the point that the Standing Orders Committee was concerned to bring out. The rights that we have here should be shared rights and not rights which are occupied by one honourable senator to the exclusion of the rights of other honourable senators to participate in a debate.

I may be wrong about this, but I would have thought that the talent in this Senate was such that anybody here would be capable of saying everything that needed to be said on a particular topic, if words were chosen with precision and spoken concisely, in half an hour. It has never been my view that it is necessary for honourable senators as talented as the ones we have here to take an hour to deal with a particular topic very thoroughly. I put to the Senate the strong view that half an hour in relation to a second reading debate is quite sufficient for most honourable senators to put their views explicitly on a particular topic, bearing in mind that in the context of a party house, as this place is, they will have colleagues who will be wanting to put similar or complementary points of view to the ones that they are putting.

TALK.START.PARA: —That does not apply to the first reading stage of a Bill.

—I am not dealing with the first reading issue yet. I found Senator Colston's remarks on that matter even more penetrating and I want to deal with those remarks separately if I may. I am dealing with the half-hour limitation in relation to a second reading debate. I put it seriously to the Senate that we have a finite amount of time and the question is how we share that time or those rights, not how we assert an individual's rights to the exclusion of those of other honourable senators who wish to contribute to a debate.
—Let us make it a quarter of an hour.

—The recommendation is not for a time limit of a quarter of an hour; it is for half an hour. I am not departing from the recommendation. If any honourable senator wants to recommend one of a quarter of an hour we will debate that matter again. I put it to the Senate that that is the appropriate consideration to take into account.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator McLaren raised an important legalistic point, if I may put it in those terms, when he said that sometimes a Minister, in introducing a Bill, speaks for more than half an hour. If we cannot accommodate that sort of situation in this place and let a Minister finish-perhaps by way of exchange we could give Senator McLaren 10 minutes extra or something like that when he speaks to the matter-I think we are really in dreadful trouble. We want the place to work as efficiently as it is humanly possible for people to work in the sort of iron lung in which we find ourselves. I think that point could be overcome.

On the question of the limitation of time in the first reading stage of a Bill, I do not feel as strongly about that issue as I do about the first issue. Again, I think the Standing Orders Committee is trying to encourage in the first reading stage of a money Bill a situation in which a number of honourable senators could contribute concisely and so on about particular points. Again, it is not a question of asserting individual rights; it is a question of sharing the time, as far as possible, so that we can get as many contributors and as much participation as possible in relation to the first reading stage. I should have thought that the nature of speeches made in the first reading stage of a money Bill would particularly lend itself to short, concise, compelling, incisive, direct, forthright speeches--

TALK.START.PARA: —Repetitive.
—Unrepetitive speeches which would appeal--
—Why put an arbitrary limit on it?

—We put an arbitrary limit on it because some honourable senators might think that their speeches were so precise, incisive, short, penetrating or whatever that they would want to repeat themselves when as a matter of fact they can probably do it very well in 15 minutes.

SPEECH.PARA: So what the Standing Orders Committee's report is about is encouraging the use of talent in the Senate; encouraging the development of the skill of saying things precisely, to the point, directly and so on, improving the cut and thrust -to adopt an expression of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser)-of debate in this chamber, and making sure that the capacity of all honourable senators to participate in that debate is assured rather than having some honourable senators being excluded by the indulgence of others. I commend the Standing Orders Committee's report to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robertson Sen E.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak also as a member of the Senate Standing Orders Committee. I wish to reinforce the point made by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and Minister for Health, Senator Peter Baume, that the recommendations which have been put forward are not government initiatives. They arise out of the work of an all-party committee. I think it would be unfortunate if any honourable senator who entered into the debate did so with the idea that perhaps the present Government will gain some advantage from it. I assure all honourable senators that the members of the Committee, as an all-party group, were looking to protect the interests of the Parliament rather than those of a government at any particular time.

SPEECH.PARA: The recommendations that were made grew out of the responses to a questionnaire sent to honourable senators. In other words, although we have had some speakers against the propositions that have come forward, the questionnaire has indicated quite clearly-two to one-that honourable senators are in favour of the propositions. We went through this exercise particularly because we wanted to make sure that we were accommodating not just those honourable senators who speak with the loudest voices or put forward the strongest arguments but the majority of honourable senators.

The suggestion has been made that a 30-minute time limit might encourage better speeches to be made. Let us hope that, as Senator Button suggested, honourable senators will learn to restrain themselves to a 15-minute speech and those who are speaking in the ordinary debates will restrain themselves to a 30-minute speech.

One honourable senator made a suggestion and, as we are speaking not as members of a party but as members of the Senate, I can comment on that suggestion. Senator Grimes suggested that we should have some sort of demonstration to show that 30 minutes is a better time limit. I put it to Senator Grimes that that is exactly what we are trying to do. This is a sessional order to see whether a 30- minute limit is a better proposition. We want to see whether this will be a better idea. Matters that come within the Standing Orders or matters that come within sessional orders are always open to change at a later stage. Certainly we will never know whether 30 minutes is a better time limit unless we give it a try.

I wish to reassure another of my colleagues who said: 'In 1919 we had an hour and a half and we still had the same in 1975 but we changed it. What a terrible thing! What will we do next? Will we have five minutes or 10 minutes?' I do not wish to be facetious about this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are.

—I make the point that in 1919 there were 36 honourable senators in this place. We now have 64 people who have to be accommodated. So it is not a very dramatic change. I turn now to the suggestion concerning a 15- minute time limit for first reading debates. Again this was suggested in response to the questionnaire and is the request of the bulk of the people here. I believe, going back to the argument that we have just raised, that we must give ourselves more chance to speak. If we give honourable senators half an hour each to speak on a first reading, that means that half the number of honourable senators will be able to speak than if we allow each honourable senator 15 minutes. We have lists on our board of 15 and 16 honourable senators who are waiting to speak on a first reading. By the time each honourable senator has had half an hour on the first reading stage, the matters many wish to discuss will no longer be relevant as they will be debating them three weeks later.

SPEECH.PARA: If we have a matter which needs to be brought forward in a concise way, as Senator Button has said, surely we ought to try to allow as many honourable senators as we can to speak in the time available. The recommendation is that we try a limit of 15 minutes. I reinforce again the point that Senator Button made. It is not the rights of individual honourable senators that I am concerned about now but the rights of the total group. Certainly there is no doubt in my mind that I would rather have ten honourable senators getting 15 minutes each than five getting half an hour each. That is protecting the rights of the individual by allowing them to bring their matters forward. On the subject of a Minister's second reading speech, a suggestion made by one speaker was that perhaps Ministers could be accommodated by the Opposition. If the rest of us have to speak for 30 minutes, surely Ministers can contain themselves to 30 minutes. If gold rusts, what then shall iron do? After all, Ministers have people who write their speeches for them. Let us face it: If it is a shorter speech it will probably be an improvement. Another suggestion was made that we should have first readings on a Wednesday. I make no comment at all about this matter. It is not part of what we are talking about.

Let me, with those few brief comments, add to what has been said by others. I remind honourable senators that this is not a government initiative; it is a matter that all parties have looked at. We are looking at, firstly, trying to improve the quality of speeches, secondly, trying to give honourable senators more opportunity to speak on broadcast and non-broadcast days, on first readings and other debates and, thirdly, looking towards making the whole situation flow more evenly. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As one of the more notoriously brisk, incisive and short-winded speakers in this place, I do not feel personally that I will be in any way prejudiced by any of these new rules and for that-among other reasons -I will not vote against them. I rise to make only one small point, and that is that I think it ought to be acknowledged openly by speakers on both sides of the chamber that there are exceptions and that extensions of time ought not to be churlishly withheld, certainly not for partisan reasons, in those exceptional cases. I think there are two obvious classes of exceptional cases that I can think of and certainly of which I have been guilty-if that is the word-of employing to speak rather longer than half an hour. Those two classes are these: First of all, when there is a very large and compendious Bill encompassing a broad range of subject areas which simply cannot be dealt with other than superficially in a very short time, it is my experience that often the Committee stage in these matters can be quite considerably shortened without setting a number of hares running that other people will pick up, if an honourable senator can build into a second reading speech of a slightly longer duration than would otherwise be the case, the various specific points that that honourable senator wants to make and which could technically await the Committee stage but perhaps could be more conveniently dealt with at that stage. SPEECH.PARA: I think the other obvious exception that we have all been aware of from time to time is the case where some actual or potential abuse is being alleged of some individual, where allegations are being made of misconduct of some kind or another or potential misconduct, where people's reputations are on the line and where, accordingly, I think it is important for those alleging the matters in issue to do more than simply make some rhetorical and often superficial statements perhaps accompanying them by a mass of tabled information but which, of course, will not be easily reported at the time because it cannot be easily absorbed by those who are listening to it. I think that, for example, is very much the kind of situation that was in issue on that perhaps notorious occasion when I spoke for about 75 minutes, an occasion referred to, I suspect, by Senator Colston earlier on the alleged financial dealings of Sir Garfield Barwick a couple of years ago. I do not suggest for a moment that occasions of this kind are always appealing to the other side of the chamber. However, I do suggest that it ought to be acknowledged that they are the sorts of occasions where, if the matter is to be raised at all in the Parliament, it is important that it be done properly and carefully and that, accordingly, it be that kind of occasion when an extension of time is granted. If the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) or someone else on the other side would acknowledge openly on the record now in the course of this debate that that ought to be the case in the sorts of instances that I have mentioned and perhaps some others as well, I for one will be perfectly happy to make the new norm that which is proposed by the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.
