Who knows, there may be an occasion when Gareth Evans has something to say which is interesting and which will take an hour. What is more, the same can be said for Senator McLaren. In any case, if they speak for too long, the Whip can impose the discipline. I recall the many times that I have sat alongside a member who was going beyond his time in the closing stages of a debate.
—And they ignored you.
—No, they did not. It was hard work, I must admit, but it did have its effect. In the end-
—And you and I had no friends left at the end.

—Yes, that is so. In spite of the nervousness of the leaders in this place, in the end we did achieve our program. I think we ought not be truncating our debates. I think there is no need to formalise the proposition which allows for the limiting of time from an hour to half an hour. Senators very seldom take an hour. I come to the proposition allowing for a 15-minute speech on the first reading of a Bill. The first reading debate on a money Bill makes this place very much different from the other place. It allows a senator to make a statement which may be of great concern, and to make that statement clearly and effectively during a general debate. What we are endeavouring to do here is to make of the first reading debate a short grievance debate as it is in the other place. I do not know whether that is entirely necessary.
—You make it half an hour and I will support you.

—I do not know whether it is necessary because I do not believe that there has been any stonewalling in this place. Senators could make one or two points, depending on the time of the day or night and the importance of the subject. It is very seldom that stonewalling occurs now. There seems to be no need to further truncate the speaking time of senators. We have accepted already the device of the incorporation of second reading speeches. This device has saved the Senate many hours. I do not think it is necessary to go any further. I think it ought to be left to the good will of the senator concerned and also to the discipline that the Whips impose and the arrangements which the various parties come to. I oppose this proposition.

—I rise briefly to support the half-hour limit on speeches. I do so because I was amazed by a statement made earlier by Senator Colston that he could remember only two occasions since he has been a senator when any senator spoke for an hour. I became a senator at the same time as Senator Colston. I can remember on many occasions senators speaking for the full hour. I well remember then Senator Reg Wright from Tasmania speaking on constitutional issues on a number of occasions. He spoke also on the Hursey case . On one occasion, he spoke for an hour on the Remuneration Tribunal and I think he was only half way through his speech. I also remember great efforts from Senator Harradine and Senator O'Byrne when they carried out some 15-round bouts over the history of the Australian Labor Party in Tasmania and the history of the Labor Council in Tasmania. I suppose I really do not blame Senator Colston for forgetting those speeches because most of them were very forgettable. But I can remember them and I can remember the details. For those reasons alone, I certainly will be voting for the 30-minute limit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —For different reasons, of course, than those outlined by Senator Sibraa, I will be supporting this proposition. I will do so on the understanding that no doubt honourable senators who will be supporting this proposition will have regard to the fact that sometimes it is impossible, within the half hour, to deal with all of the matters which one would like to deal with when addressing oneself, say, to the debate on the second reading of a Bill which is before this chamber. I am attracted to the proposition because it puts Wednesdays which are broadcast days on the same basis as Tuesdays and Thursdays. In other words, on Wednesdays the extensions provisions could apply, as I understand this proposition. That is attractive because if, for example, industrial legislation came before this chamber on broadcast day, the Government presumably putting it on on that day because it expected, forlornly I might say, to get some political propaganda out of it, if one were expected to deal with it in an intelligent manner then it might be difficult to deal with it within the half hour. Under the present Standing Orders, a senator would have half an hour and that would be that. Under this proposition a senator would be enabled to indicate to the Senate that he would not have time to complete his remarks and therefore would be enabled to move presumably as he would still be on his feet, for an extension of time of 15 minutes.
—There is nothing in this sessional order that guarantees you that at all.
—As I understand it, the new Standing Order 407A states:

SPEECH.PARA: No Senator shall speak for more than thirty minutes in any debate in the Senate . Any Senator may move that the time limit of thirty minutes be extended for fifteen minutes; such motion shall forthwith be put without debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —You can now.
—Not on a Wednesday.
—You will not win but you can.
—Can we do that on Wednesday now?
—You will not get it, but you can.

—If the debate is being truncated and if the majority of honourable senators are for the proposition being put, I feel that those honourable senators would be understanding in the event of some honourable senator wanting to complete his or her remarks and would move a motion that the time be extended by 15 minutes. Under those circumstances I will support the proposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALKER.NAME: Senator PETER BAUME
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and Minister for Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will respond to a couple of points that have been made during this debate. When I speak I am not speaking for the Government; the Government does not have a view on the Standing Orders. An honourable senator said that this is a Senate debate; I am speaking as a senator. Since I have come to this place there has been a change in the way honourable senators approach their work. We have a younger Senate; we have, by objective measurement, a better educated and fairly active Senate. A lot of honourable senators want to take part in debates. As Senator Button said, the problem is to try to make available, to the greatest number of honourable senators, a chance to participate in debates.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind those who have taken part in this Committee debate that the last motion that was passed put aside more of the time that might have been used for Government business for a Senate purpose; that is, for the consideration of committee reports. Senator Button said in his speech that what is required is to seek a mechanism to give a greater number of honourable senators a chance to participate in debates on Tuesdays and Thursdays and to participate in debates at the first reading stage. If more speeches can be made, we will represent our electorates better. What is being proposed in the new Standing Order is a means of achieving that.

There is a situation now where if one can anticipate special circumstances, and generally one can, arrangements are often made between Whips, or in the case of Senator Harradine between him and the various groups in the chamber or between the Australian Democrats and the major party Whips. Efforts are made to try to accommodate special circumstances and special needs. That has always been the case. The provision here is explicitly spelt out so that honourable senators have a capacity to move for an extension of the time beyond the limit. The whole thrust of what we are out to do is to try to put alongside the further extension of the consideration of committee business a provision which will allow more honourable senators to take part in general debates during the week. This can only be for the good of the Senate.

Having been guilty, certainly in the past, of making some long and boring speeches, my own observation of my own performance would be that when one had to prepare a speech to deliver within a time limit it was generally a better speech and was, as Senator Button said, a tighter, better organised speech. That is simply my personal recollection and observation. That is often the case for many honourable senators. I acknowledge that there may be special circumstances and special situations for which special arrangements are required. I think that is a matter for the Senate to decide. I do not believe that either in the proposal to bring the speaking arrangements for Tuesday and Thursday in line with Wednesday or in the proposal to make new arrangements for first reading debates honourable senators will lose anything. All that is required is that we prepare our material with rather more care. I think that the debates will be more interesting and that we will lose nothing in the presentation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a few remarks on what Senator Button has said. He mentioned that honourable senators can make good speeches if their words are chosen with precision; that by doing that, and by ensuring the adoption of the new time limits on speeches we encourage talent. Unfortunately not all honourable senators have facilities similar to those of Senator Button and Ministers. Senator Button, as can Ministers, can speak in the Senate from notes or from a speech in draft. The points in those notes are gone over with a fine tooth comb by staff and when the speech is delivered it can be read. It is received very well and it reads well in Hansard.
—I have never given a good speech like that.

—I hope in the future the honourable senator does not do that, because he has done so in the past, as have Ministers. This is quite against Standing Order 406. If a back bencher, particularly on the Opposition side, endeavours to read a speech he is smartly brought to book. This has been referred to occasionally on the Government side, not so much on the Opposition side. The point is that if we are going to introduce recommendations to change Standing Orders to improve the performance in this place we also ought to give the President full authority to enforce Standing Order 406 so that Ministers and the leaders on this side of the chamber have to go through the same trauma as back benchers. They will then make speeches, which in a lot of cases, may not read as well as speeches by back benchers, although it will take them a little longer to deliver them. All honourable senators who vote for these propositions today should not even ask for or expect to get extensions of time. They have signified in their speeches today and will signify by their vote that they do not want them. They are going to condense their speeches and show the talent which Senator Button spoke about. What will happen on Budget night when the Leader of the Opposition is given 30 minutes to reply to the Budget?
—No, he is not. There will be a special motion, Senator.

—That may be one, but there will be many others. If it suits the Ministers, or if it suits the Leader and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition they will get special circumstances but Joe Blow sitting on the back bench will get nothing at all. That is why I say that Standing Order 406 should be rigidly adhered to. Of course, it will have to be policed in the future. Our Whip, Senator Robertson, spoke about the questionnaire that was circulated to honourable senators. He said that the result was two-to-one in favour of the proposition. He did not give us details as to who supported the reduction in speaking times.
—Secret ballot.

—Yes, I know it was. Many of those people who have voted to reduce the time available very seldom rise in this place to utter a word. They come in here week after week and say nothing. They will be the ones who will support the recommendation. These honourable senators who want to say something probably would not have supported the proposal. The matter that disturbs me greatly regards Senator Walters. If she is going to vote for this motion to restrict her speaking time to half an hour three days a week and 15 minutes for first reading debates, how will she develop a speech when she stands up there as she does on most occasions and lambasts the trade union movement? She will not be able to do it in 15 minutes. So she will be in trouble, as this is the main theme of her speeches.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Robertson said that there is a long list of honourable senators wanting to speak in first reading debates. By the time they get the call the material that they want to use is stale or out of date. That was never the case before. An honourable senator could rise immediately and speak to the first reading motion of a Bill. For some reason unknown to back benchers that has all been changed. We can only speak in first reading debates on Thursdays. If some business takes place and first reading speeches are not made on Thursdays there is then a week's adjournment or three weeks' adjournment like we have just had and in the Whip's room there is a list a mile long of honourable senators who want to speak. It might be a month before honourable senators get the opportunity to speak in that debate. By that time the matter is stale because first reading speeches are allowed only on Thursdays.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not so, Senator.

—That is my understanding of the matter. I am pleased the honourable senator has informed me that the position is different. If I have a current matter I want to raise the next time a first reading debate is brought on I will feel quite free to get up and speak to it. For the reasons that I have outlined I think the Senate is running into great dangers if it adopts these proposals. Some honourable senators are not afraid to point this out. If honourable senators seek an extension of time we will remind them that they did not want the time initially. The members of the Standing Orders Committee must have given very serious thought to these recommendations. My leader Senator Button is a member of the Standing Orders Committee. I am sure that when he agreed for this proposition to come forward he gave serious thought to the time limit he imposed upon himself as well as the time limit he imposed upon the back benchers. As I said, he has more of an advantage because he can say a lot more in 30 minutes with a prepared speech compared with honourable senators on the back bench. We have to do our own research as well as attend to all the other duties we have in the Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: When a Bill is brought on for debate we often have to speak off the cuff. I venture to say that a lot of the speeches that are made off the cuff in this place get right to the nub of the problem. They are far better than some of the prepared speeches by Ministers, front benchers from our own side and others. There are many occasions when our speeches find the kernel of the problem much better than some of these prepared speeches. When one has a prepared speech one does not know what will crop up. If one answers a few interjections one is thrown right off line. Certainly, if this measure passes-apparently it will- honourable senators will not get an extension of time. Matters will just be left in limbo. People listening to an honourable senator on the radio on Wednesday or reading the speech the next day or the next week in the proof copy of Hansard will not know what the honourable senator is on about. They will know what the people who were speaking off the cuff were on about. They were not allowed to read their speeches. For those reasons I will oppose both the propositions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had expressed previously in other places some concern about the limitation of time on speeches. But having listened to the debate which has taken place I begin to wonder whether my concern is misplaced. Having heard some of the contributions that have been made and the length that they have taken I just begin to wonder whether we should at least not give a trial to some method of imposing some limitation. I therefore propose to the Senate-as a compromise between those who wish to see permanently enshrined in the Standing Orders the limitation which has been proposed by the Senate Standing Committee on Standing Orders and those who are opposed to any change at all-the idea that for a trial period by sessional order there be the change to see how, in fact, it operates. I would feel considerably happier if that were done. After, say, two sessions of trial we could see whether people still hold the same view as passionately as they do now that there will be some real loss to the Senate of its opportunities to operate as a Senate. I therefore propose formally and at the appropriate time will move that this be done by way of sessional order rather than by way of amendment to the Standing Orders.
—Will you move an amendment?
—I put it forward at the moment. I will move the amendment when the opportunity arises.
—Are you moving it now?
—Mr Chairman, I will move it now if that is your wish. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the proposed amendment to Standing Order 407A operate only as a sessional order for a trial period.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to say something about the contribution of Senator McLaren. This is a very sensitive topic. I must at this stage in all seriousness say that the degree of sensitivity is such that I feel somewhat hurt. Senator McLaren in his contribution suggested that I, as a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Standing Orders, in advocating a limitation of time had been thinking about the effects of a limitation of time on me but not on anybody else. I assure Senator McLaren that when I was thinking about a limitation of time I had him in mind as much as myself, if not more so. My action was not done on any partial basis at all; it was done on the basis of equity, at least between Senator McLaren and me . The only other thing that upsets me about Senator McLaren's contribution is that he comes into this debate as the man with the greatest facility for words in the Senate.
—Second greatest.
—Here is the greatest.

—I do not want to enter into a parochial issue between two of my colleagues as to who has the greatest facility for words. Senator McLaren with the great facility for words complains here that he, of all people, could not confine his remarks to half an hour. I find that incredible to believe from somebody who has the flow of language that Senator McLaren has. I really think he is not doing justice to himself in this debate. I want to make those comments only because I regard this as an important issue. I want it to have the support of Senator McLaren as well as everybody else.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier in the debate I outlined my opposition to both proposals-the proposal to limit general speeches to 30 minutes and the proposal to limit speeches in the first reading debates to 15 minutes. I am not so intent on trying to see that opposition succeed that I would not like, perhaps, to see it work in the Senate for a little while. I therefore commend the proposal that Senator Peter Rae has put forward. It may be that, after we have seen this plan in operation for some time, those of us who oppose it at the present time might not any longer see any need for opposition. On the other hand, the situation might arise that those who have proposed these matters at this time see after that trial period that it is not working properly or it is not working effectively in the Senate and, therefore, it would be much easier for us to revert to what we have at the present time.

SPEECH.PARA: If we enshrine these propositions in the Standing Orders at the present moment I can foresee that it would be very difficult for us to revert to what we have at the present time. We would have to go through the whole debate again. We would have to have a report before us. That would be a most cumbersome prospect for us to go through. I therefore commend Senator Rae's proposition to honourable senators. However, if the motion is passed in its proposed form I ask : What do we mean by a sessional order? How far does it go? I would be interested to know whether it would be just for a session, whether it is for this session and the autumn session or for the whole sitting of this Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is renewed or not renewed each session.

—That would mean that we would have a debate on this matter again at the beginning of the next session if this proposition were passed. Before resuming my seat I will reply to one matter which Senator Button has mentioned. He spoke about the rights of honourable senators. He said that some of us were concerned about our rights being taken away. I would be more concerned if the rights of our constituents were being taken away. We are not here to speak for ourselves. We are here representing people from various States and the two Territories. Those people sent us here expecting us to do our duty by them. If rights are to be taken away it is the rights of our constituents that will be taken away, not our own rights. I commend Senator Rae's proposition to honourable senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —When I participated in the debate earlier I indicated that most honourable senators take no more than half an hour-sometimes less-to speak in debates. One or two honourable senators might take a full hour on a matter which they considered to be important. If this proposal were to be implemented for a trial period one would not object to that period of half an hour in which to speak. We could see how many people get to the end of half an hour and find that they need more time. I do not think we will find that happening very often except in some of the more complicated debates that may take place. Even then, I suppose, an honourable senator could take up many of the matters in the Committee stage of Bills. I do not feel inclined to go to the barricades over the half hour limitation on Tuesdays and Thursdays as well as Wednesdays.

SPEECH.PARA: However, I have strong feelings on the next proposal found in recommendation (b ). I do not think the first reading debate ought to be truncated in this way. I am assured by Senator Robertson that first reading debates on Bills do not come forward only on Thursdays. I think this occurs by government arrangement. If the Government has any astuteness at all it will not bring on the first reading of a Bill on a broadcast day. It certainly will not do so when it has important business. The first reading debates are generally set down for a Thursday anyhow . The Government by arrangement of the business program makes certain that first reading Bills do not interrupt the flow of debate. My view is that if a first reading debate takes place it should be treated the same as all other debates; that is, if we agree to recommendation (a) in paragraph 4, recommendation (b) ought to read half an hour.

For that reason, I intend to propose formally-if you, Mr Chairman, put the question separately-that, recommendation (a) having been agreed to, recommendation (b) be amended to read half an hour. That would prevent a speech in a first reading debate on a Thursday or a Tuesday going for the full hour, as it does at present. It would merely go for half an hour. My view is that 15 minutes is far too short a time in which to make an important contribution to a debate on the motion for the first reading of a Bill. In moving that amendment, I will suggest that we take the matters separately and when recommendation (b) is put to the Senate I will move that there be a limit of 30 minutes on the speaking times in debates on the first reading of a Bill which the Senate may not amend and that the Standing Orders be amended accordingly. I am not saying ' special'. I am merely taking out the word 'special'.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Georges, I suggest that if you propose the deletion of the last paragraph of the recommendation in Appendix C your point would be taken up by the first paragraph, which reads:

INTERJECT.PARA: No Senator shall speak for more than 30 minutes in any debate in the Senate.
Therefore, I suggest that if you wish to move a further amendment you should move for the deletion of the last paragraph.

TALK.START.PARA: —That would have exactly the same result. Therefore, I will move formally for the deletion of the last paragraph. That would bring the time limitation for first reading debates into conformity with that for the rest of our debates; that is, half an hour. If we accept Senator Rae's proposition we will also give ourselves a period to reconsider. At the end of three months or six months we can take a look at it and see just what limitations the half an hour limit has placed upon the Senate. In view of the fact that, as I said before, very few honourable senators have taken their full hour, I cannot see any reason for opposing recommendation (a). I strongly support the deletion of recommendation (b).

SPEECH.PARA: However, I want to make one further point. From an Opposition's point of view-I might be being critical of those Opposition members on the Standing Orders Committee-these moves facilitate a Government more than they facilitate an Opposition. I know that there will be a change of positions in this place and I expect that there will be a change at the next election. But historically the Labor Party has been in opposition more often than it has been in government. What we are doing is facilitating the ease with which a Government runs its program. That really is not the responsibility of an Opposition. The responsibility of an Opposition is to have as many devices as are available to it to frustrate the Government if what the Government is opposing is not acceptable or is, perhaps, reprehensible. There ought to be devices available to an Opposition. Sometimes the device may be lengthy speeches made at the appropriate time in order to postpone proceedings. It might be a postponement for only two or three days. It might be necessary to postpone legislation and not to allow legislation to be passed. What we are doing, of course, is making it easier for the Government to get its business through. I make that comment from an instinctive position which I have taken in the past. I have responded immediately to some of these propositions of the Government-especially those proposed by the Government Whip-with a 'No' because the Government was seeking to advantage itself. It looks as though I am going to drag Senator Grimes into the debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a terrible argument.

—It is not a terrible argument. It is a very positive argument. One of these days we will find that we have given away certain devices which we need in order to frustrate the government of the day. I do not doubt that when the present Government becomes the opposition it will do exactly as it did last time. It was entitled to do that. If honourable senators recall exactly what the Opposition did when we were in government they will appreciate that the then Opposition used every method available to it under the Standing Orders to frustrate the Government's program. It was its role to do that. I might remind Senator Button--
—You are against the Government.
—Yes. I am Irish by nature, if not by race. But let me say it is the responsibility of the opposition to frustrate the government, especially on certain issues.
—Keep them honest.
—No, sometimes it is necessary to delay the passage of legislation. What we are doing, of course, is facilitating the Government's ability to get the legislation through as quickly as possible.
—You can get more speakers up.

—No, it is not so easy to get the extra speakers up sometimes. Yes, that is a means by which one can do it. Senator Mason can bear that in mind . In any case, I have said enough on the matter. It is just a matter of that instinctive reserve I have to say no to anything the Government proposes. It may be unusually stubborn or a dog in the manger sort of attitude. Nevertheless it is a particularly sound position to take. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the last paragraph of the proposed amendments to Standing Order 407A, as set out in Appendix C of the Standing Orders Committee report, be deleted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I propose to put the question at the appropriate time that the words proposed to be left out from the proposed amendment to Standing Order 407A be left out, that is, the last paragraph.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak briefly. I believe Senator Rae's amendment is sensible partly because it is clear that the new limitation on times will in fact go through. I suppose that is partly due to some of the arguments that have been put by people in opposition to it. I must say that I take the reverse view to that taken by Senator Georges. I believe that the ability to speak on what an honourable senator wishes in a speech in this place on the motion for the first reading of a Bill is in fact a quirk of this place. It is in fact a time for grievances. If an honourable senator cannot get his grievance over in a quarter of an hour, I think he should propose it as a matter of public importance or raise it in the adjournment debate or at some time like that when an honourable senator can take longer.

SPEECH.PARA: My argument and the argument I used in the first place is simply that I think we are going about this matter in the wrong way. We have had two people-Senator Evans and Senator Harradine-who have said: 'We will vote in favour of the limitation of time to half an hour'. But they have both said: 'But when we want extra time we will seek an extension and we expect to get it'. With due respect to the two honourable senators, they are people who are always after extra time and who will always need it in the future because they are two people who happen frequently to make speeches for more than half an hour.

TALK.START.PARA: —Be fair. The circumstances are identical.

—I am being fair. The simple fact of the matter is that the vast majority of the speeches made in this place go for less than half an hour. On a few special occasions some people speak for more than half an hour. As Senator Peter Baume and I have demonstrated since we first arrived in this place, we are able, by self-discipline, in most cases to limit ourselves to less than half an hour. I see no harm in the present time limit of an hour on those Tuesdays and Thursdays. If someone finds himself in the circumstances in which Senator Harradine and Senator Evans sometimes find themselves and he wants to go for a bit over half an hour he in fact can do that without any difficulty.

SPEECH.PARA: We have heard a lot about senators' rights and I am not one who uses that sort of argument at all. I think we get obessed with what we think are our rights in this place and I think we mistake what the word means. But if we reach the circumstances whereby we are having some sort of war of attrition in this place, it is the easiest thing in the world for the majority group in this chamber to stop people from getting the extension of time they need. Then people such as Senator Harradine and Senator Evans may find themselves in trouble when they should not be in trouble.

As I have said, it is clear that the half hour limit proposition will go through. I fail to see-no honourable senator arguing in favour of it has demonstrated this to us-how it will improve the workings of the Senate. Everyone here knows that people very rarely speak for longer than half an hour. No one has taken out any figures to try to demonstrate how the new limit will make more time available for debate. One would not be able to demonstrate that by limiting the speeches to half an hour we would improve the situation. I accept where the numbers are. As I said earlier, I accept some of the reasons for the numbers being where they are. I will therefore support Senator Peter Rae's amendment, which I think is eminently sensible. I do not support Senator Georges's amendment for the reasons that I gave earlier.

TALK.START.PARA: — From what Senator Grimes has said, it is clear that my previous support for the proposal was based on a false premise. I had been under the impression that existing Standing Order 407A precludes the moving of a motion on broadcast day for the extension of an honourable senator's time. Clearly that is not so. There is an ability under existing Standing Order 407A on broadcast day for an honourable senator to move for an extension of time . In those circumstances, for the reasons that I gave previously, it is clear now that we will not gain anything from the proposition before us. Therefore, I must admit that, having made up my mind to support the proposition on a false reading on my part of existing Standing Order 407A, I am now persuaded to vote against the proposition and I will do so accordingly. The fall back position, of course, is that proposed by Senator Peter Rae. I will support that proposition.

—I just mention that I was under a misapprehension when I was speaking earlier about the sessional order. I understood that, if we passed Senator Peter Rae's motion, we would probably look at this proposition again next session- that is, in my mind, the Budget session. I think Senator Georges was probably under this misapprehension too. He mentioned that we would perhaps look at the proposition again in three months' time. I am informed that a session, in parliamentary terms, is the length of the Parliament. That means that we could conceivably go until the end of 1983 before we looked at this matter again.
—I talked about a year or more. I am sorry if I misled you when I was answering.

—I am sure that the honourable senator did not mislead me. I was misled by my own definition of a session. We often speak of the autumn session or the Budget session and I was using that terminology. Of course, I am told that if for some reason the Parliament is prorogued in the meantime that is the end of the session. It could be prorogued for some special reason, for instance, if we wanted to have the Parliament opened by the Queen when she is in Australia later in the year. We would look again at the Standing Order at the beginning of the next session, which could conceivably be at the end of this year. But the most likely event, it seems to me, is that the session will go until the end of 1983. In that case the sessional order would apply until then and we would have to look at the Standing Order again in the early part of 1984. Whether the fact that the year would be 1984 has a relevance, I am not sure.
—It is a bit long.

—Yes, I feel that it is a little long. I just wonder whether there is any way in which we can look at this sessional order at, say, the end of this year or at the beginning of next year. I am not quite sure whether we can do that. If Senator Peter Rae's motion is carried, it would seem to me to be better that we look at it at, say, the end of this year or the beginning of next year to determine whether we are still in favour of it and whether it should continue. If we wait until the end of next year, the proposition may become part of the folk lore of the place and, even though there may be some disadvantages, we may be disinclined to change it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to alter the amendment which I moved a short time ago to include the words 'sessional order to operate until 31 December 1982'. That will mean that the concerns which have been expressed are catered for. The matter can then be dealt with at the beginning of the autumn session next year. I think that that will ensure that the trial period takes place and that a review will take place when the Senate sits next year.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martyr Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened to this debate for most of the afternoon-some time in my office and a little time in this chamber. I have yet to hear a fundamentally sound reason why there should be change. We have been told-it has been emphasised-that at present honourable senators rarely use all of the time available to them in debate. That is fair enough. My memory of the situation, from the short time in which I have been here, is that that is true. Why should we formalise that discipline which honourable senators are already imposing on themselves?

SPEECH.PARA: Quite obviously, when honourable senators have had enough to say, when they have made their case, they sit down. Very rarely in here do honourable senators talk out their time. There are occasions-Senator Georges alluded to them-when the tactic is used, quite properly so, by the Opposition. I do not have the same dreadful expectations about the future that Senator Georges has. I do not anticipate that in the future honourable senators presently on the Government benches will be on the Opposition side and senators presently on the Opposition benches will be on the Government side. I do not want to hear any suggestion of any party political advantage in the debate. It seems to me that we have been given no good reason at all. It seems to me that a change has been proposed almost for change's sake.

I could see the advantage, even though I voted against it, of trying new sitting hours in the Senate, but, regardless of whatever good reasons were put forward for changing those hours, there does not appear to be any sound reason for the proposition now before us except to formalise the self-discipline that honourable senators have exercised in the place. That is not a good enough reason for me to want any change at all in the Senate.

I think that, as has been well pointed out by others, there will be occasions- very rare occasions-when somebody needs more time. Indeed, I suppose I have to personalise that remark by saying that the only occasion since I have been a member of the Parliament when I feel that I will need more time than is allowed- about half an hour-will be during consideration of the family law matter which is to come before us soon. The subject has been before us previously. I feel that I will need a lot more time in which to speak on that matter because I have a particular interest in it.

I know that honourable senators have other interests and they will want to take up their allotted time. Senator McLaren, who is trying to interject, has his interests, too. He wants to take up his time and he uses it well. I suppose that , in common with everybody else around here, I do not like to be here after midnight listening to him use that time well, but he is entitled to do so; and I have been here keeping him company while he has been doing that. Fundamentally, I think, Senator McLaren and I are at one. Senator McLaren's proposition is that the Standing Orders be left as they are. That is my proposition too. I say so simply on the grounds that no really good reason has been put forward for formalising the discipline that honourable senators already impose on themselves . So, with great pleasure, I will vote against all the new propositions.

Item 3. Petitions

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALKER.NAME: Senator PETER BAUME
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and Minister for Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the existing sessional order relating to the procedure for the presentation of petitions be replaced by the following proposed sessional order:
Notwithstanding anything contained in the Standing Orders, the procedure for the presentation of petitions is varied, as follows:
(1) A Senator wishing to present a petition shall lodge it with the Clerk.

(2) The Clerk shall make an announcement in respect of petitions lodged with him, indicating in respect of each petition the Senator who presents it, the number of signatures, the identity of the petitioners and the subject matter of the petition.
(3) Every petition so presented shall be deemed to have been received by the Senate unless a motion, moved forthwith, that a particular petition be not received, be agreed to.
(4) The terms of the petitions presented shall be printed in Hansard.

After the uneventful and non-controversial debate which has just passed, I am sure honourable senators will find the next proposal to be a matter of little controversy. It concerns the practice in the Senate of reading petitions. As honourable senators will see in the report of the Standing Orders Committee, it is suggesting to honourable senators that it may wish to consider an amendment of that practice, namely, that the reading of the text of petitions be abandoned , that all petitions presented by honourable senators be lodged with the Clerk and that the Clerk read a summary of the content of petitions. The Standing Order has been drafted to give effect to that. Honourable senators might ask: What is the purpose of a petition being presented in the Parliament? It is, of course, an ancient right for citizens which has to be taken seriously by honourable senators.

The only question before the Committee is the form which that should take. How should a petition be put into the Parliament? It is irrelevant what happens in any other place, but one may ask again: How can we use the time of the Senate best? How can we do it in such a way that still allows petitions concerning matters of importance to come before the Senate so that the Senate is made aware of those petitions, yet perhaps modify the present practice which is considered by some honourable senators to be not the best use of the Senate time and to be one during which not a lot of attention is paid to the detail of the petitions themselves?

If the new sessional order is adopted, the Standing Orders Committee would recommend-this is included in the report-that Mr President would as a matter of practice have a list of all the petitions circulated to honourable senators so that those senators who want to have the content of a petition taken up by a particular Senate committee may be aware of the substance of the petition and may in fact then seek a reference from the Senate so to do. The Standing Orders Committee has been trying to seek a means by which petitions can be received and by which the subject matter can be made known to the Senate but which will avoid the quite lengthy and often unproductive way in which the presentation of petitions has been done until the present. I commend the recommendation of the Standing Orders Committee to the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I oppose this proposed change. I think it is a great shame that this should have come before the Committee. I believe that even in considering it we are forgetting a very important fact-that we represent people in this place. The people of this country who, when they feel strongly enough about something to get off their butts and to collect tens or hundreds of thousands of signatures, do so with a purpose. They have a very ancient right at least to petition this place and to have the feeling that their petition is heard in some kind of way. I have listened to the way in which petitions are presented in the House of Representatives. It is an absolute farce; it is a disgrace. There is no reason why petitions should even continue to be presented in that place, judging from the way they are handled now.

SPEECH.PARA: In the last session of this Parliament I moved a motion, which I will be shortly moving again in this session, which would enable a large enough petition containing half a million signatures to demand action to put matters to referendum. That, I think, is something which lies in the future for this country. Meanwhile, I think it essential that we allow a voice from the people to come into this place. It is the only one they have, with respect to those of us who are delegates, the representatives of those people, members or whatever we call ourselves. They rarely enough have their views put forward by people in this place. I think it is an ancient right.

The use of broadcasting has given these petitions a certain amount of clout. I do not deplore the fact that we get many petitions on a broadcast day. I do not regard it as a waste of time. The feedback I get from people in the electorate is that they do not regard it as a waste of time. When those many thousands of people who sign those petitions hear that at least the fact that they have done so is getting through to the rest of the community through the broadcasting of the Senate, they feel that something of importance has happened. I will cite one small example. Petitions concerning lead in petrol were presented in this place last year by a number of honourable senators. Every broadcast day, and virtually every other day as well, those petitions were presented. I cannot believe they did not have a considerable effect on community feeling and possibly on the view of government. It was designed to be that way. Those people, many of whom were members of parents and citizens organisations, got those petitions together because they felt that there was some value in doing it.

We all know that when petitions hit this place no further action is taken about them. But this is, after all, a parliament. It is a place of debate. It is a place where things are discussed and talked about. To refuse the right for the want of a little of our time, to say that perhaps another 10 or 15 minutes speaking time for one of us is more important than that the voice of those people should be heard here, is a great disgrace. I oppose the motion and certainly I shall vote against it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I call Senator Georges.
—Here is the old conservative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: — Yes, I am a conservative. But if I am a conservative, where does that place the honourable senator? I seems to me that the responsibilities of those on the Standing Orders Committee are even greater than they thought they were, judging by the way we voted last time. It is fairly obvious that whatever the Standing Orders Committee decides upon will be supported by the Senate. Participation in the debate is such that when the vote comes about more than half the honourable senators do not know what they are voting on.
—They certainly should not be allowed to speak for more than half an hour if they do not know that.

—All I am suggesting is that the honourable senator's responsibility on the Standing Orders Committee, especially as he is an Opposition member of the Standing Orders Committee, is far greater than I thought it was previously; and I thought it was a fairly heavy responsibility. Let me now look at petitions. We are now going again to shorten the program, for our convenience, because we are not prepared to listen to petitions being read. There are two ways in which petitions are presented in this place. An honourable senator makes a decision as to whether a petition will be read. He or she makes a decision as to whether it will be given to the Clerk. At that point he or she makes his or her own determination. That facility is there. But no matter how we feel about time and no matter how boring some people may think it is, why should we withdraw from a group of people the right on a broadcast day to have a petition read-not a summary, but the petition. Petitioners are entitled to that right. It is an ancient right, as an honourable senator said. But whether or not it is ancient, it is a worthwhile right.

SPEECH.PARA: One may say: 'What good does it do? It achieves nothing'. That is another matter we would need to take a look at because, depending on the nature of a petition, it is possible for an honourable senator in this place to refer that petition to a standing committee-it has been done-or to take some other action, depending upon the importance of the petition. A number of people-it may be 20, 30,300 or 500-decide that a petition shall be presented by their senator. The honourable senator says that the best time to present that petition is on broadcast day, a Wednesday. As it happens, that is the day on which an honourable senator generally asks for a petition to be read.

It has been said that on broadcast day in this place at about 2 o'clock or 3 o' clock in the afternoon-the exact time escapes me at the moment-there may be 5, 000 or 6,000 people throughout Australia, which is not many people, listening to the broadcast either by accident or by intent. Many people are politically attuned and do listen to the broadcast. Out of a total of 14 million people, 5, 000 or 6,000 is not very many. Nevertheless, 5,000 or 6,000 people do listen; I think the ratings show that. That is 5,000 or 6,000 people to whom that petition is read. Very few of us can at any time gather together an audience of that size to which to put a point of view, and our petitioners at present have that right. What do we want to do? For our convenience now we are going to have a summary read. We already have, in part, a summary. If an honourable senator determines that he or she has already presented a petition on a number of occasions, he or she says: 'I do not want the petition read. I want the Clerk to deal with the matter'. That is a decision that can be made, and surely that is sufficient. It worries me that the Standing Orders Commitee, for expedient reasons--

TALK.START.PARA: —What expedient reasons?
—What other reason is it for?
—We have to stop kidding people.

—In what way? If Senator Grimes puts it that the petitioners are kidding themselves by presenting a petition to this Parliament he will further erode the position of the Parliament. That might be overstating it.
—Preserve the fiction.

—I have seen the fiction in Queensland gradually eroded to the point that one cannot gather a petition there. In other words, one has to get a petition privately. One cannot stand in a public place in Queensland and gather a petition. It is against the law to do so and one can be arrested for so doing. People have been arrested for trying to gather petitions. That is a serious limitation of the right to petition the Parliment and the Crown. Furthermore, a group of people are not able to present a petition to the Parliament in Queensland. They face arrest if they do because they are in breach of the traffic regulations. The traffic regulations in Queensland are now superior to and take precedence over the rights of people to petition. In a small way we will continue this erosion because honourable senators are not prepared to spend 20 minutes listening to petitions being read.
—But you are never here during petition time.

—Senator Robert Ray has not been a senator very long. Before he starts making criticism such as that he ought to recall the times when people have sat in here endlessly. Maybe my record over the past 12 months has not been the best, but this debate today has inspired me with the need to participate more fully even if it is to the disadvantage of my own colleagues. I hope it is to the disadvantage of the Government. But it seems to me that there is still an important role for people who have been here too long, who have become jaded and who have become cynical. I put myself in that category, but I am not as cynical as most of those who support this proposition. They have become cynical to the extent that they are not prepared to listen to petitions being read. It may be said that as I support this proposition I should listen to the petitions being read. I will do so but I hope that others join me if that happens. Getting back to the right of people to petition and to appear to be petitioning-that is what the matter is all about-what we want to do will in some way reduce that right.
—That is not so. Please read the proposal.
—I am reading the proposal. Senator Grimes intends that -this happens to a lot of the petitions in this place-petitions become a summary read by the Clerk. The petitions will not be read in full.

—Read the next paragraph. What happens to them then? What happens to them now? They disappear now. At least they will go to the Chairman of Committees and to all senators, and if you want to do something about it you will do it.

—I do not deny that that ought to be the case, but as far as the people making the petition are concerned it is not heard, and it ought to be heard in the first instance. I am not denying what Senator Grimes is suggesting- that is an improvement-but let us add it to the existing situation; that is, have the petition read if the honourable senator so desires at the time. That is most important. The other things can also flow. We might be arguing a small point, nevertheless it is an important point. Again, it is a matter of choice by the honourabe senator as to what happens to the petition-whether it is read or is part of a summary. Also, once a petition is read for the first time it is not read a second time the same day, so why should we go further and exclude it altogether?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the proposal of the Standing Orders Committee. I draw the attention of honourable senators to what it states. In essence, it provides that there be a summary of the contents of a petition read by the Clerk; but it further provides, as Senator Georges acknowledged in his answer to Senator Grimes, who put a telling argument by way of interjection, that the President adopt the practice of sending petitions to the relevant standing committees, for example. Where Senator Georges's and Senator Mason's arguments fall down is that it is not sufficient to assert that it is an ancient right to make it necessary for that practice to be continued. Senator Georges said it is the right of every citizen to hear his petition read. How about the right of those whose petitions are read on Tuesday and do not have the opportunity to hear them read?
—They can read them in the Hansard.
—The point is that those petitioners who have their petitions read on a Tuesday will not hear them being read.
—They will not hear it but--

—I will deal with Senator Bonner's views after I have dealt with those of Senator Georges, if he does not mind. That is a point which Senator Georges seems to regard as very important. He is concerned not about the hundreds of thousands of people who sign petitions but about the 2,000-odd people who listen to the proceedings of this chamber on broadcast day. Perchance some of them may have signed a petition and had the opportunity of hearing it read, which would produce a state of great elation, no doubt, in the petitioners . That, if I might say so, is a great exaggeration of the factual situation and an extraordinary proposition because they as petitioners have rights which ought to be accorded to them on Tuesdays as well as Wednesdays. In essence, the proposal of the Standing Orders Committee seeks to make this Parliament more relevant. The package of matters we have dealt with today are directed towards that point: Involving honourable senators such as Senator Georges in debates much more frequently than they have been in the last few years and giving every honourable senator a right to contribute as much as possible to a debate by limiting the time for which some of us speak in order that others may contribute . Limiting the time to speak at the first reading stage of money Bills will enable as many honourable senators as possible to make precise, to-the-point contributions.

SPEECH.PARA: If I might venture a view, all that the reading of petitions involves by way of community participation is the actual honourable senator doing his thespian stunt of reading the petition on the day in question. That is all the process adds to the relevance and dignity of this Parliament-a bit of reading by honourable senators-and we are not all former Australian Broadcasting Commission employees, such as Senator Mason, who reads them well. What is important, of course, about the collecting of petitions in this community, if we are frank and honest, is the involvement of members of the public in being concerned about an issue confronting this Parliament and discussing it with their neighbours, workmates and colleagues and getting them involved to the point at which they read a petition and say: 'I am concerned about that, too. I will sign it'. That is the important community process. Those people ought to know that when the petition comes to this chamber something relevant is done with it, not just having it read out and put in the dustbin of history, because that is what Senator Georges is arguing for.

TALK.START.PARA: —No.

—That is the present system. I beg Senator Bonner's pardon but that is the present system which Senator Georges has defended. The Standing Orders Committee has suggested a much more relevant way of dealing with petitions: Firstly, seeing that they are not read in great detail over the air because, whether we like it or not, that stuff does not make good ratings for the Parliament, and, secondly, seeing that contents of the petition are drawn to the public by a summary read by the Clerk and then referred to the relevant standing committee for consideration. That is a more constructive approach than the system which now exists.
—Who will determine which is the relevant standing committee?

—I assume that the Clerk would do that, just as at the moment he determines which archives they will be consigned to the moment they have been read. I do not see why he should not peform that function with great skill and diligence. The proposal, in my view, is a constructive one. It is designed to improve the system and to alleviate all those people in motor cars from the boredom of listening to petitions being read at great length, and switching off. We would like them to remain tuned into the broadcast in order to listen during the additional time which will be available for debate. Senator Mason raised an important point when he said--

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I speak briefly on a matter of interest to the local Manly-Warringah community in Sydney. I bring to the attention of the Senate the fact that a local newspaper, the Manly Daily that circulates throughout the Manly-Warringah district-the district incidentally in which I live-has been judged for the second consecutive year the best suburban newspaper in New South Wales. The Manly Daily is delivered daily to more than 73 ,000 homes in the Manly-Warringah area except on Sundays and Mondays. It is estimated that it is read by more than 150,000 people each day when it is delivered. I believe it is certainly read more widely in the Manly-Warringah district than are the metropolitan dailies. SPEECH.PARA: This is very important because an increasing number of pensioners in the district cannot afford to buy the daily papers and get their news from the free throwaway paper. The Manly Daily is dedicated to publishing purely local news keeping Manly-Warringah residents up to date with local government issues, activities of local politicians and local events. I believe that the paper is a strong unifying force in the community. It takes part in community affairs and charity events on a regular basis. As far as the sporting news is concerned, it is first class and regularly has more up to date information than the metropolitan dailies especially in regard to those local teams that represent the district and the composition of those teams.

I have not always agreed with the editorial policy of the paper. In fact, during the last Federal election I violently disagreed with its editorial policy . But I must point out that at any time I have written letters to the editor about any complaints that I have had they have always been published. I think the coverage of political events in the district is fair and accurate. I am sure that my State colleagues, Tom Webster, the honourable member for Wakehurst, and Alan Stewart, the honourable member for Manly, would agree with me. I also strongly agreed with the campaign that the newspaper ran against the tax on information-the sales tax that this Government proposed to put on newspapers that this Senate rejected. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a matter which not only concerns the quite appalling treatment of an individual but also raises an important issue of principle about the administration of government employment. This is the background to the matter: In February 1981, Press reports appeared to the effect that the Australian Federal Police were investigating criminal records and making other so-called character checks on officers of the Attorney-General's Department. On 24 February last year, I asked the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) in the Senate whether and by what authority such checks were being carried out and what the fate would be of any member of his Department who refused to consent to such a check being made. On 26 March 1981, the Attorney supplemented his original rather brief oral answer with a written answer. I seek leave to have that detailed answer incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Durack

TALK.START.PARA: —On 24 February 1981 (Hansard, page 12) Senator Evans asked me the following questions without notice:

INTERJECT.PARA: (1) Is it the case that character assessments are presently taking place in the Attorney-General's Department whereby all employees, including those who have no access to classified government documents, are being checked for such apparently irrelevant or ill-defined characteristics as 'undeclared homosexuality' or a ' loose tongue'? By what authority, legislative or administrative, are these checks being carried out? Are they being carried out or will they be carried out by any other department? If such action is not directly connected with the protection of highly sensitive classified material, what is the policy underlying such checks?

(2) Having agreed to further investigations, will the Attorney do two things: Firstly, undertake to table in Parliament forms that persons are being required to fill in and also any supporting documentation governing the procedures now applicable and, secondly, will he tell us what the fate of any member of his Department who refused to give consent to this procedure would be in practice?
The answers to the honourable senator's questions are:
(1) For the purpose of this answer officers in my Department and throughout the rest of the Public Service may be put into two categories.

The first category consists of officers who have or may have access to classified material. In respect of these officers, my Department obtains a security assessment from the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation. This clearance is obtained in accordance with the new security procedures adopted following the Australian Security Intelligence Organization Act 1979. In addition, after receiving the consent of the officer, my Department obtains from the Australian Federal Police details of any criminal charges involving the officer pending before a Court together with details of any conviction of finding of guilt which has been recorded against him. Alternatively, the officer is permitted to obtain a certificate as to those matters from the Police Force of each State or Territory in which he resided in the past five years. These procedures are, I understand, followed by all Departments.

The second category consists of officers who do not generally have access to classified information. The Department does not obtain a category assessment in respect of these officers. However, before a person is appointed to the Public Service, my Department, with the consent of the person concerned, obtains details of any criminal charges pending before a Court together with details of any conviction or finding of guilt recorded against him. Alternatively, the person may obtain a certificate in relation to those matters from the appropriate Police Force. I understand this is the practice followed in all Departments for officers in this category.

For a short period recently, my Department commenced to apply the procedure used on appointment of the second category of officers to all serving officers. The purpose of this was to provide maximum flexibility in the future deployment of staff.

The Permanent Head has now concluded that this procedure will not be generally applied to serving officers who are in the second category but may be applied in the case of promotion or transfer of officers to positions of special trust within the Department.
(2) Copies of the forms that persons have been asked to fill in are attached.

In the case of an officer in the first category, a person declining to fill in the necessary forms may be regarded as ineligible for promotion or appointment to the position. If the person is already occupying the position, consideration would need to be given to whether he should be transferred to a position not involving such access.

In the second category, a person refusing to consent to the AFP providing the statement or to provide the certificate from the relevant Police Force mentioned above might be regarded as ineligible for appointment. As explained above, in relation to serving officers, the question will arise in the future only in relation to positions of special trust. A refusal to follow the procedure mentioned may result in ineligibility for promotion or transfer to such a position.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I will briefly summarise that answer since it is highly pertinent to the case I am going to describe. The Attorney-General said that for these purposes public servants could be divided into two catergories. Category one consists of those officers who have access, or may have access, to classified material. An Australian Security Intelligence Organisation security assessment is made of these officers and, with their consent, details of their criminal records obtained. Category two consists of those officers who do not generally have access to classified information. In this category a security assessment is not obtained. But, before appointment and with the consent of the person concerned, details of criminal records are obtained.

SPEECH.PARA: The Attorney-General went on to give the following answer in relation to a refusal to give consent to the obtaining of a criminal record:

In the case of an officer in the first category, a person declining to fill in the necessary forms may be regarded as ineligible for promotion or appointment to the position. If the person is already occupying the position, consideration would need to be given to whether he should be transferred to a position not involving such access.
In respect of persons in the second category-that is, where there is no access to classified information-the Attorney continued:

. . . a person refusing to consent to the AFP providing the statement or to provide the certificate from the relevant Police Force mentioned above might be regarded as ineligible for appointment . . . in relation to serving officers, the question will arise in the future only in relation to positions of special trust. A refusal to follow the procedure mentioned may result in ineligibility for promotion or transfer to such a position.

In a moment I shall have some remarks to make about the inappropriateness of any question of access to criminal records of persons applying for positions which have no security sensitivity. Right now I just want to proceed to outline a particular case which appears to have been conducted in direct contravention of these guidelines set out by the Attorney-general.

The officer in question, whom I will not name for reasons which will become obvious although I know her name, is employed in the Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office in Sydney. She commenced employment there in July 1979 as a legal officer . She was employed as a temporary employee under the Public Service Act and still retains that status. She is a temporary employee nearly three years later. Her work in the DCS Office throughout has been in common law litigation. At first her work concerned bankruptcy and, since August 1981, she has been in a section dealing with negligence actions against the Commonwealth, mostly involving personal injury claims. None of this work is remotely security sensitive by any criterion, and certainly it does not involve the officer in question in access to classified information. Without doubt she is an officer in the second of the two categories identified by the Attorney-General.

Late last year, the officer in question applied for permanent employment in the usual way. Following a series of interviews, she was recommended for permanency. I should point out that, while her employment status was to change, she was to continue to do precisely the same work as before. She was duly sent an application for permanent employment together with a request that she sign a consent form authorising the Federal Police to provide to the Attorney-General's Department details of any criminal charge pending against her and of any conviction recorded against her. At this stage, I seek leave to incorporate again in Hansard the form in which this request was made. I have drawn it to the attention of the Attorney-General and he has indicated no opposition.
Leave granted.
