TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I should point out that before admission as a solicitor of the Supreme Court of New South Wales, which event occurred more or less contemporaneously with her appointment to the Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office in the Public Service of the Commonwealth, this person had been required to swear an affidavit in relation to any convictions she might have had. Her affidavit attested to the fact that she had none. It is my belief-as I will make clear; I do not perceive this to be relevant to the force of the case-that there is no question of any convictions ever having been recorded against her or any such action having been pending. But, as I say, that is my belief and that is only marginal to the point that I want to make. Understandably enough, she refused, as I understand virtually all the serving officers in the Department had themselves refused, as a matter of principle, in February 1981, to sign this consent form. She regarded it as an unjustifiable invasion of her privacy and one that bore no possible relationship to the nature of her employment.

SPEECH.PARA: Furthermore she was, although a temporary officer, an officer of some years standing within the Department. She took the view that that fact ought to be taken into account. An element of humiliation was involved in seeking consent to the search in question. According to the Attorney-General's guidelines, which I described at the outset, refusal to give consent should only affect a serving officer in a case of promotion or transfer to a position of special trust, which this case clearly was not. Yet, following her refusal to give consent, the Attorney-General's Department notified her on 14 April-just a couple of weeks ago-that unless she signed the consent form she would not be accepted for permanent employment and furthermore that her temporary employment would cease on 30 April 1982, this coming Friday. That is, not only is she being, I believe, unfairly prevented from upgrading her employment status following a favourable recommendation by the relevant selection committee but also she is about to be sacked for her refusal to consent to what I regard as an obnoxious procedure.

I wish to register the strongest protest at this conduct which I can only perceive to be vindictive conduct by the Department. I believe it is an affront to anyone who is concerned about civil liberties, to anyone committed to enlightened employment practices and to anyone who believes in elementary standards of fairness. This threat of dismissal is nothing short of bullying by a department which is determined to get its own way against someone who does not even have the appeal rights of a permanent public servant. The Department's action is justified neither-I put this very strongly-on the merits of the case as I perceive them and which, I believe, speak clearly for themselves nor by reference to the Government's guidelines in relation to serving officers in which category she clearly falls, albeit as a temporary officer.

I refer again to the guidelines described by the Attorney-General in his written answer to me of 26 March 1981. I call on the Attorney-General, who I wish were here in the chamber since I gave him notice that I would be raising this matter, to take immediate action to revoke the dismissal notice and to ensure that the recommendation for permanent employment is speedily confirmed without any further absurd requirement to consent to scrutiny of the kind that is proposed.

Finally, I will simply comment more generally for just a moment on the fact that there is no apparent reason why the Commonwealth, as an employer, should be in any different position from a private employer in matters of this kind when it comes to obtaining information about the criminal records, if such exist, of applicants for employment. I had occasion recently to investigate this question in the context of the Victorian Police Force and I was impressed, I must confess , to discover just how stringently the Victorian Police Force appears to control employer access to criminal records. The only employers who can get access to such records are those who are engaged in genuinely security-sensitive business such as drug manufacture, security and surveillance services and who apply to the Police Commissioner for authorisation and obtain the written consent of the applicant in question.

Other employers in Victoria have no access whatsoever to criminal records however much they might like to have such access and they are prohibited from making it a condition of employment that an applicant give the consent in question. I assert that the same principles should apply to the Commonwealth and that outside that sector of Commonwealth employment which is genuinely security sensitive-using the Attorney-General's category 1 description-it seems to me quite insidious that there be any requirement to consent to access to records. I believe that this practice should be immediately abolished, as a general matter, quite apart from the particular case of what appears to be clear injustice being resolved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to refer to a situation in which a reputedly distinguished Australian became very much less of a renowned figure when he misjudged the appropriateness of the occasion and the response from the audience as to the form and content of his address. The setting for this loss or reduction in reputation was at the graduation ceremony of the Tasmanian College of Advanced Education last Saturday night when Robert John Hawke abused the privilege which was granted to him in presenting a sound, reasoned, researched and academic address on a matter of substance. If Bob Hawke could do no more than present a closely read speech, a monotonous monologue of partisan attack on unemployment which could be heard on almost any day of the week in Parliament, I think this great Rhodes scholar has indeed suffered great deterioration of mind since his heyday.

SPEECH.PARA: Lest this be regarded as an uncharitable approach let me assert that surely those who have been building up this image around him have found that he is incapable of sustaining that image during the 1980s. A possible explanation of this unusual behaviour must surely be the cavalier attitude of Mr Hawke to the feelings of others, particularly the graduates and their families. The approach was discourteous, not only to the chairman but also to the principal, the graduates, their families and the many guests. It was an unfortunate occasion but I think Mr Hawke used the occasion knowing full well that there will be a State election in Tasmania where the issue of spending limits has been critical to both parties and candidates. Therefore, candidates and parties use every possible device that they are capable of putting forward in order to reach a very wide audience. I believe if this was the tactic it was despicable to use this occasion to this end. Mr Hawke spoke for approximately 40 minutes to an increasingly--

TALK.START.PARA: —Fifty.

—He spoke for forty minutes to an increasingly restive audience. In fact, a number of people left. The figure has been put at about 50. At last a speech and drama student got up and said: 'We have spent four years leading up to this night. I think it is our night and not yours'. The applause that that young student got was thunderous and most appropriate to the occasion. Never have I seen a speaker so cut short in his remarks; he was certainly cut to the quick. Almost to a man I think that audience acknowledged the sensitivity and correctness of that girl's remarks. I think it was unfortunate that Mr Hawke used this occasion to deliver what one must say was a most inappropriate address . He took unfair advantage of what would have been a captive audience. After four years of grinding study there were people present who felt that this was not the occasion to deliver what I call a monotonous monologue on matters relating to unemployment, inflation and industrial relations. The address was far removed from what the occasion required. I think this is the essential point to bear in mind.

SPEECH.PARA: It was a sad day for the College which is trying to establish itself as an identity in the community. The setting was grand. For the first time the magnificant Albert Hall was used. Over 1,100 people were there. I think it was regrettable that after four years some of the students went away from that hall and wept because they were so disappointed. Other citizens came to that hall expecting to hear an oration from a person who is supposedly one of Australia's greatest debaters. Unfortunately, their great expectations were not realised.

I certainly would like to see Mr Hawke make an apology to the College and to the citizens of Launceston for the inappropriateness of his remarks on the occasion and for the manner in which he delivered the address. It was also unfortunate that he took so little interest in the students receiving their awards that night. It was not only his remarks that were unfortunate but also his lack of interest in those students who passed by him to receive their awards . Because of that I would ask that he restore some dignity to the occasion by making a public apology. Lest any honourable senators believe that my remarks are inappropriate or inaccurate I ask leave to have incorporated in Hansard the Mercury newspaper report of 26 April 1982 headed: 'Hawke jeered at ceremony'.
Leave granted.
The article read as follows-
Hawke jeered at ceremony
Federal ALP front-bencher, Mr Hawke, was interrupted and jeered by students as he addressed the 1982 graduation ceremony of the Tasmanian College of Advanced Education at Launceston on Saturday.
Mr Hawke, the guest speaker at the ceremony, had spoken for about 25 minutes on unemployment and alternative Government policy when he was interrupted.
A student stood and said to Mr Hawke, 'We have spent four years leading up to this evening. I think it is our night not yours'.
Most of the 200 graduating students supported this with applause and jeering.

In reply Mr Hawke, the Labor spokesman on youth affairs, employment and industrial relations, put away his prepared speech and said he had tried to make a contribution that he thought would deal with the future that the graduating class faced.
He said he realised some of the students may have thought he was using the time to put across one point of view but said the issue of unemployment 'transcends Labor and Liberal party policy'.
He said it was something that happened in society that could not be blamed solely on Government.
After Mr Hawke's speech, the chairman of the council, Mr E. A. Rouse, said Mr Hawke 'spoke to us with a great deal of sincerity and depth of feeling on a subject that affects us all'.

In Mr Hawke's speech he had urged the Government to concentrate on unemployment first and inflation second. He said 'the commitment to a goal of full employment had disappeared from the political arena during the 1970's.
'Government policy in Australia and other countries has become obsessed with controlling inflation'.
Mr Hawke's alternatives included creating a 'more expansive fiscal policy', a ' modest increase in the public sector', taxation changes and a development of works programs in local communities.
He said fighting inflation before unemployment had failed and it was time to tackle unemployment first as had been done successfully in Sweden, Austria and Japan.
At the ceremony, attended by more than 1,100 people, more than 200 graduates received their masters and bachelor degrees and diplomas.
A second ceremony will be held at the TCAE's former Mt Nelson campus on Saturday. The guest speaker will be Prof. Wendall Smith.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: — I feel obliged to respond to the remarks of Senator Watson and to make one or two points that may be relevant. Until I heard Senator Watson speak I was not aware of the incident that occurred. It seems to me that someone was remiss in not having in some way set the program for that evening. Although there was a keynote speaker it is usual on these occasions that the keynote speaker is told that he has 20 minutes to speak. Whenever I chair any conference, function or seminar that is fairly clearly indicated well beforehand to the person concerned. It seems to me that someone failed to indicate that on such an occasion this would be the requirement. Nevertheless, I would need to read what Bob Hawke did say. What he has expressed to groups of students on previous occasions was his concern that having gone through long periods of study and having achieved their qualifications the employment environment is such that their expectations are considerably limited.
—It was about 40 pages and it was the same old dreary stuff.

—I would suggest that the honourable senator should take a look at who was the chairperson on that occasion and find out just exactly why it was not made clear that such an amount of time was available. Perhaps Bob Hawke did misjudge. I think that if he did misjudge sufficient criticism emerged on the night and in the Press to satisfy even Senator Watson, but he brought this matter into the Senate. In other words, he wishes to rub it in. If Bob Hawke was in error he wishes to push Bob Hawke further down. I can say only that on the occasions when Bob Hawke has prepared material he has prepared it with preciseness. He has prepared it with care. In fact, looking from my point of view, he has been far too academic. But he has been academic because he believed the propositions he was putting were important. Perhaps he mistook the situation and made this a forum to present that point of view.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to take a look at that speech he made. I think it would have been relevant to the position in which most of those students would have found themselves, having achieved their qualifications. My view of it is that throughout Australia there is now an extreme difficulty on the part of graduates to find employment. Many youngsters find themselves unemployed for long periods. Many government schemes-the National Employment and Training System and other employer-supported schemes-try to assist at the level of pre-tertiary education. But once the youngsters have gone through tertiary education and got their qualifications they are, in fact, in a very serious position in relation to employment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Every one of them had a job, every single one.

—It is very interesting to find that out because in Tasmania they are doing much better than they are in Queensland. I can take the matter home. I have a son who did a master's degree in zoology. He took a year off in order to find employment. The only two jobs he found in that 12 months were, firstly, loading Coca-Cola crates on a truck and, secondly, working at a drive- in bottle shop in a hotel. He was forced to go back to university and do a doctor of philosophy degree. We all know exactly the trauma, the poverty and the actual despair that most doctor of philosophy students go through in four or five years. He is now waiting for his assessment which he is told will take a minimum of six months. It might even take 12 months. He has no employment prospects whatsoever and he is not the only one. Many others in his stream are so placed. If Bob Hawke spent time on putting forward this case he put it forward with a considerable amount of justice. Politicians have a problem. I have spoken for five minutes now. I suppose, possibly, if I get wound up I will go for longer. If I had a captive audience I would be tempted to go for longer. In fact, I have a captive audience at the moment. I could go on.
—Don't count on it.
—Of course I will not. We do have those limitations. I think it is unfair to press that criticism further.
—What about the unfairness to the students, their parents and the other people?

—I think they may have been suitably unimpressed by that, if what Senator Watson is saying is correct. However, I still would say that there was considerable value in the document Bob Hawke presented.
—You haven't read it.

—I said before that I had not read it. I said before that I have read other documents written by Bob Hawke. I have read the transcripts of various lectures he has given. I said before that I found them to be precise, well-prepared and maybe academic. Sometimes I feel that he has lost me but I am easily lost in these matters and I need to come back and ask for much more simple explanations of the problems. But honourable senators cannot deny that Bob Hawke was invited because he was a person of standing. Being a person of standing he should have been allowed a certain amount of time to present a case. If he over-presented that case I would say that somebody did not properly advise him and I would take a look at the people who organised that ceremony. I doubt whether they will fall into the same trap next time.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us put the credit side as far as Bob Hawke is concerned. He has been responsible for a substantial number of achievements in both an academic way and an industrial way. He is now in the political area and, possibly, that is to his disadvantage because once a member has been in this place too long he becomes loquacious and submerged in trivia. He possibly does not understand that he must get out of the rarified atmospheres in which he has worked for so long and get back to giving a few odd platitudes at an opening or presentation. But I do not think he is that sort of person. I do not think he should make a few odd remarks , smile, sit down and say, 'Have a good year and congratulations on getting your diplomas' et cetera. He is much too serious a person for that. If that is what the College of Advanced Education wanted it should have invited me, but if it wanted something more substantial it did the right thing by inviting Bob Hawke. If he overextended his welcome that is perhaps unfortunate. But I think he is now aware of it and he certainly will not make the same mistake twice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Having heard Senator Georges I can only indicate my views as one of those who were present at the unfortunate events of last Saturday night at the Tasmanian College of Advanced Education graduation ceremony. Senator Georges said that he was quite sure that there was value in the document which Mr Hawke had prepared. I am not sure for what reason it had been prepared. I had the distinct impression that it was being recycled or was being used as a trial run for a different occasion.
—You didn't agree with it, that is your problem. You didn't agree with it, so you were at a disadvantage before you started.

—Just a moment, please. It was a document which had been prepared as if it were for a speech to be given in Parliament or at an election rally organised by the Australian Labor Party. It referred throughout to the iniquities and incompetence of the government of the day and to Mr Hawke's party 's policies in relation to all of these matters. I think every one of us is fully aware of the fact that on such occasions there are ways in which we can discuss a subject without making it quite so obvious that we are grinding a party political axe. I have had a considerable respect for Mr Hawke's capacity on such occasions to give a reasoned address and I was surprised that his speech was so blatantly party political.
—This was a graduation ceremony.

—This was a graduation ceremony, not a seminar as Senator Georges suggested. It may have been far more appropriate if it had been a seminar. But it was a ceremony at an excellent and relatively young college attended by a group of young students all of whom were trying very hard to develop a standard of excellence. I have been to a great number of graduation ceremonies around Australia and this was one of the best that I have ever been to. As Senator Watson said, the hall was excellent. When I heard that Bob Hawke had been invited as the guest speaker I had no thoughts that his address would be other than an excellent and appropriate one. Senator Archer agrees that it was a most unfortunate occasion.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish very briefly to describe a part to which Senator Watson referred and to join him in the request that he made. What happened was that after some 40 minutes or more Mr Hawke, seeing that people had been leaving the large hall for quite some time and that there was restlessness, made some reference along these lines: 'If you will bear with me a little longer . . .'. From what one could judge, quite a few pages of the notes from which he was reading remained. It was at that stage that a young, and I think fairly brave, graduate stood up and made the remark to which Senator Watson has referred. She said that the students had worked for four years for that night and that it was their night and not Mr Hawke's. The situation was further compounded when Mr Hawke endeavoured to continue to read parts of the speech and for a second time said: 'If you will give me another two or three minutes . . .'. Nobody objected to that although there was a little murmuring in the hall. The next time he said: 'If I can just have another two or three minutes . . .' the response from the hall was quite strong, to the effect: 'No, sit down and shut up. You have already had too long' .

It was a most unfortunate event. I feel particularly sorry about the embarrassment to the college, to the principal, to the council and particularly to the graduates. I believe that it was a very public occasion. Mr Hawke had obviously intended it to be a political occasion, because he had distributed copies of his speech, or a summary of it, to the media in advance for the purpose of publication in the Sunday Press in Melbourne and Sydney- all over Australia. Such reports would not emanate from some reporter who was at the ceremony that night. Rather, it was used as a political occasion which would lead to headlines such as 'One million unemployed in Australia, Hawke says'. This was obviously an intentional act of using the invitation given to Mr Hawke by this college for a party political exercise, for distributing around Australia a speech which was intended to be, and was, an attack on a party political basis putting forward alternative policy points of view. Some of us may agree that unemployment is greater than it appears from the statistics and that other points in what Mr Hawke had to say may have been valid. But it was the way in which his views were expressed, as a party political axe grinding exercise, which offended so many of the people, including many Labor supporters, who were in the hall that night. It was the most incredible display of insensitivity and rudeness. I believe that all those concerned deserve an apology from Mr Hawke. I join Senator Watson in asking whether Mr Hawke will make such an apology.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 8 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Have foreign investors been increasing their ownership of meat processing plants in Australia, as well as rural properties.

(2) Does ownership of both livestock properties and meat processing factories give such foreigners a capacity to artificially control the market in their own interests, which are not necessarily those of Australian farmers.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Over recent years the meat processing industry had been undergoing structural change as a result of over-capacity, fragmentation and intense competition. Many abattoirs are operating at less than 50 per cent of capacity and a large number have been closed.

(2) During this period of change over the past five years, the Government has considered thirteen proposals for foreign investment in the meat processing industry (excluding poultry, fish and smallgoods). If all the proposals considered had been implemented, the resulting increase in foreign ownership in the industry would have involved total assets of about $55m.

A number of proposals entailed acquisitions of only a small percentage of the shareholding of the target company and in several cases the effective increase in foreign ownership was only marginal. Furthermore, not all of the proposals eventuated.

Three of the proposals have been of significance to the industry. The first was the acquisition by Amatil Ltd of the whole of the issued capital in T. A. Field Holdings Ltd in 1977 for a consideration of $12.8m. Field was reported as being the fourth largest New South Wales meat processor at the time of the acquisition , the second largest retailer of meat in New South Wales and a significant exporter. Amatil has since become a naturalised company in terms of the Government's foreign investment policy.

The second proposal of importance was the acquisition in 1978 by Waitaki NZ Refrigerating Ltd of New Zealand of just over twenty per cent of the enlarged issued capital in F. J. Walker Ltd. Walker holds a substantial position in the Australian meat industry. The proposal was expected to lead to benefits primarily through the combined exporting strength of the two companies.

The most recent proposal which was approved in March 1982, involves a merger of the pig and processed meat activities of F. J. Walker Ltd with Canada Packers ( Australia) Pty Ltd. This proposal will not involve any net loss of Australian ownership and the merged business will be jointly Australian/ Canadian controlled. There will be national economic benefits through industry rationalisation and increased efficiency.

The radical changes occurring in the industry over a number of years makes estimation of the level of foreign ownership and control difficult since closures of some abattoirs will seriously affect the figures. Further, the $55m increase in foreign ownership referred to above needs to be seen in perspective having regard to the fact that in 1979-80 turnover in establishments in the industry exceeded $3.3 billion while value added during the period was around $ 776m. In short, there has not been a substantial increase in foreign investment in the industry in recent years and the investment that has been permitted has been designed to help the industry in the difficult situation confronting it.

(2) A substantial number of meatworks in Australia compete with each other in the purchase of livestock for processing. Also, there are over 100,000 livestock holdings freely selling their stock for slaughter in a competitive marketing system. The relatively small number of cases in recent years in which foreign investment has increased in meatworks or rural properties would not have provided a capacity for the foreign owners to control the market in their own interest.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 17 September 1981 Senator Lewis (Hansard, page 828) asked me as the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Why was it necessary to purchase a house in the suburb of East Killara which, I understand, is in New South Wales?
Why was it necessary to purchase a house for $140,000 to accommodate a senior defence officer of the Army?
Are there any adjacent military establishments which would require the purchase of a house in this prime location?
What is the normal cost of building a house to defence standards on government land for senior officers?
The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The house was acquired by the Department of Defence for use by a senior Navy officer appointed to any one of the several naval establishments in the vicinity of Sydney Harbour. There is an acute shortage of housing which is reasonably close to such establishments, and which meets the standards appropriate for senior Service officers.

The house was transferred to the Department of Defence from a Commonwealth authority which previously owned it (the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation). The transfer followed procedures which normally apply in such situations: after notification that the Corporation no longer required the house, the Department of Administrative Services asked other Commonwealth departments if they had a need for it, before considering its disposal. Thus, although the house was transferred to the Department of Defence at its taxation valuation ($140,000), the acquisition involved no additional outlay by the Commonwealth, in real terms.
The current cost of building a house to standards appropriate for senior officers is around $54,000. To this would be added the cost of land, which would vary with the location.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 12 November 1981 (Hansard, page 2079) Senator Button asked me, as Minister representing the Treasurer, without notice :

ANSWER.PARA: Did the annual report of the Commissioner of Taxation released on 29 October show that at the end of the last finanial year $973m, accumulated in tax avoidance schemes and challenged by the Department, remained uncollected? Is this $200m more than the avoidance figure reported a year earlier and $550m higher than the avoidance figure of two years ago? Does the $973m accumulated in 1980-81 remain uncollected because of a shortage of personnel due to staff ceilings, or is there some other reason relating to government legislation why that figure is so rapidly accumulating?
The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

In reply to your question of 12 November 1981 regarding tax avoidance I indicated that I would ascertain the latest position in respect of the staffing levels of the Australian Taxation Office and whether the uncollected tax attributable to tax avoidance is accumulating because of staff shortages or for some other reason.

The Commissioner of Taxation has reported to the Parliament on more than one occasion that his operations have been affected by the limited numbers of appropriately qualified and experienced officers available within earlier staff ceiling limitations. However, I am now able to advise that the staff ceiling of the Australian Taxation Office has recently been increased by 324. This should materially assist the Commissioner's efforts to maximise the level of compliance with the taxation laws by all sections of the community.

In respect of the amount of $973m reported as uncollected at 30 June 1981, I would point out that a substantial part of this total relates to large numbers of schemes cases awaiting decisions on similar cases which have been referred to the courts and boards of review for hearing.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 16 February 1982 (Hansard, page 12) Senator Jones asked me, as Minister representing the Treasurer, a question without notice concerning a report prepared by the Commercial Bank of Australia relating to the underground economy.

ANSWER.PARA: The Treasurer has provided the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question:

The report prepared by the Commercial Bank of Australia (CBA), which was published in the CBA's 'Economic Review, September 1980', did not endorse the estimate of the size of the underground economy (10 per cent of Gross Domestic Product) which was prepared by the Monash Centre of Policy Studies; it preceded it and did not mention any other Australian work in this field.

The CBA report included an estimate of the size of the underground economy which was obtained by applying an approach used by Professor Gutmann for the United States. However, such estimates are inherently unreliable; moreover, Gutmann's approach is based on a number of very dubious assumptions. The authors of the CBA report clearly indicated that they were conscious of the limitations of their estimates of the size of the underground economy. Indeed, they said '. . . we do not wish to argue whether this is a correct assessment or not'.

The statistician has not attempted to estimate the 'underground economy'. Any attempt to do so would suffer from lack of reliable data on which to base such an estimate. It should also be noted that because some components of estimates of national income are based on data that would not be affected by under- statement in income tax returns, at least some of the 'underground economy' is included within estimates of gross domestic product.

Notwithstanding these uncertainties, the Government tries to minimise, as far as possible, the effects of the 'underground economy' on the collection of income tax and other revenue of the Commonwealth.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 24 February 1982 (Hansard, page 391) Senator Townley asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Has the Government, in the interests of assisting incentive and an attempt to stop some tax avoidance, considered limiting the tax on overtime earnings to a rate equal to that applicable to the top of the employee's base salary.

(2) In these times of high interest will the Government once again consider asking the Australian Taxation Office to investigate the practicability of paying interest on money retained by that office and subsequently refunded to a taxpayer.
The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

(1) The Government has considered and rejected limiting income tax on overtime earnings. The major difficulty with such an arrangement would be that the limitation could not, in practice, be confined to overtime payments. For example, wage earners who obtain promotion or who take on additional employment to increase their income, and businessmen who work additional hours for the same reason, would be regarded as equally deserving of the limited rate of tax on their increased income.

In addition to causing a loss of revenue, a general limitation of the rates of tax on all additional income would involve complex legislative and administrative arrangements. It would result in different tax being paid by people with the same earnings and hours worked but who had different basic salaries or normal hours of duty. It could also promote tax avoidance where the taxpayer was able to arrange to have a greater proportion of his earnings paid in a form that would qualify for the lower rate.

(2) The question of the payment of interest on end of year excess tax instalment deductions due for refund to taxpayers has been considered and rejected by the Government on a number of previous occasions. In considering the question, regard has been had, among other things, to the views expressed by the Taxation Review Committee under Mr Justice Asprey in 1975 that it did not favour the idea of interest payments as the practice 'would be extremely expensive and might result in delays in making refunds to employee taxpayers'.

If the Government were to decide to pay interest in respect of refunds of tax overpaid, it would be difficult to confine the application of such a policy to that particular area. The proposal would need to be considered in the light that, if interest became payable on refunds issuing after a delay in the processing of an assessment, there would be pressure for the introduction of similar measures to provide for payment of interest in other circumstances, for example, where refunds result from a review of an assessment or from decisions in favour of taxpayers within the appeal system of the tax law. The extra costs , including administrative costs, which such an extension of the proposal would involve could well ultimately require an increase in taxes and this would tend to offset any benefit of interest payments made to individual taxpayers.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 10 March 1982 (Hansard, page 642) Senator McIntosh asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Can he say whether the Government has yet found a buyer for the Australian Government Publishing Service bookshops as recommended by the razor gang? Can the Minister say whether the new method of pricing the AGPS books allows commercial enterprises to sell the publications at a far higher price than would have been charged by the Australian Government bookshops?
The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
A number of expressions of interest have been made by individuals and commercial organisations for the leasing of the Australian Government Publishing Service Bookshops.
Tender documents are in the final stages of preparation and are expected to be issued in the near future.

It is correct that prices will not be printed on future AGPS books. However this decision is entirely unconnected with commercial leasing of the bookshops. It has been done to allow AGPS to operate in a more commercial fashion following recommendations by the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Publications. Recommended retail prices applicable at particular times will continue to be published in AGPS catalogues.
The printing of prices on books has not prevented resellers from increasing them in the past, the new arrangements will therefore not change the situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 17 March 1982 (Hansard, pages 859-60), Senator Townley asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Health, a question without notice concerning the salt content in foods.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Health has provided the following information:

I am aware of Time magazine's recent article on the health problems associated with excessive consumption of sodium, particularly as salt. This is one of many articles which have appeared in the print media on the relationship between excessive consumption of salt and prevalence of hypertension in Western countries, including Australia.

The National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) established a Working Party on Sodium in the Australian Diet which first met in March 1980 to consider the matter of salt intake and its relationship to the development of hypertension.

The Working Party has now finalised its report which, it is anticipated, will be considered by the Council at its June 1982 meeting. If approved by the Council, the report will be given wide circulation.

I should emphasise, however, that my Department has already taken action to alert the community to the dangers of excessive salt intake. My Department has drawn up a set of eight dietary Guidelines for Australia to improve the nutritional health of the community: One of these Guidelines is to reduce the consumption of salt.

A publication 'Dietary Guidelines for Australians'-which includes advice to the community to use less salt and gives practical suggestions as to how this can be done-should be available for wide distribution within the next few weeks .

The matter of the declaration of the specific percentage of salt and/or sodium on the labels of packaged foods, as suggested by the honourable senator, is presently under consideration by expert Committees of the NHMRC and, indeed, was considered by the Working Party on Sodium in the Australian Diet.

The NHMRC has already recommended that ingredients of packaged foods should be declared, in descending order of proportion, on the label. This recommendation includes the declaration of added salt and has been referred to the States and Territories for adoption. Recommendations emanating from the NHMRC are, primarily, matters for consideration by the individual States and Territories as regards their possible incorporation into legislation, and several States have already adopted the recommended provisions in their food regulations.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Sale of Wheat to the Soviet Union

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 18 March 1982 (Hansard, page 927) Senator Martyr asked me a question, without notice, in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry in the Senate. His question concerned the sale of wheat to the Soviet Union.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Primary Industry has supplied me with the following additional information:

The honourable senator's question refers to the sale by the Australian Wheat Board of 1 million tonnes of wheat to the USSR for shipment in the period February to May 1982. The sale was announced by the Wheat Board in a press release of 4 February 1982.

The sale continues the regular Australian wheat trade with USSR which has been in existence for many years. It follows an earlier wheat sale of 1 million tonnes from the 1981-82 wheat crop and brings to 2 million tonnes the Board's total contract wheat sales for delivery to the USSR in 1982.

In line with normal practice the latest sale by the Wheat Board was made on full commercial terms. The period of credit was strictly short-term and the interest rate charges reflected market rates. The precise terms and conditions of Wheat Board sales are generally not made public as a matter of commercial prudence and often at the request of the buyer.

While the Soviet Union is normally a cash buyer of Australian wheat the decision to provide commercial short-term credit for the latest sale was taken on the basis of pure commercial consideration prevailing at the time and in no way represented an effort by Australia to assist the Soviet Union.
